{{refimprove|date=April 2017}} {{Other uses}} [[File:Słuchawki referencyjne K-701 firmy AKG.jpg|thumb|Headphones on a stand]] '''Headphones''' (or '''head-phones''' in the early days of telephony and radio) are a pair of small loudspeaker drivers worn on or around the head over a user's ears. They are [[electroacoustics (acoustical engineering)|electroacoustic]] [[transducer]]s, which convert an [[electrical signal]] to a corresponding [[sound]]. Headphones let a single user listen to an audio source privately, in contrast to a [[loudspeaker]], which emits sound into the open air for anyone nearby to hear. Headphones are also known as '''earspeakers, earphones'''{{cite web |url=http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/earphone |title=earphone |accessdate=4 January 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140119123425/http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/earphone |archivedate=19 January 2014 |df= }} or, [[colloquially]], '''cans'''.Stanley R. Alten ''Audio Basics'' Cengage 2011 {{ISBN|0-495-91356-1}} page 63 Circumaural ('around the ear') and supra-aural ('over the ear') headphones use a band over the top of the head to hold the speakers in place. The other type, known as '''earbuds''' or '''earpieces''' consist of individual units that plug into the user's ear canal. In the context of [[telecommunication]], a [[Headset (audio)|headset]] is a combination of headphone and [[microphone]]. Headphones connect to a signal source such as an audio [[amplifier]], [[radio]], [[CD player]], [[portable media player]], [[mobile phone]], [[video game console]], or [[electronic musical instrument]], either directly using a cord, or using [[wireless]] technology such as [[Bluetooth]], [[DECT]] or [[FM radio]]. The first headphones were developed in the late 19th century for use by [[Switchboard operator|telephone operators]], to keep their hands free. Initially the audio quality was mediocre and a step forward was the invention of [[Hi fi|high fidelity]] headphones.{{Cite web|url=http://www.stereocompare.com/headphones-buying-guide/#Hi%2520fidelity%2520headphones|title=Headphones : The Ultimate buying guide - Hi-fidelity headphones|website=StereoCompare|language=en-US|access-date=2016-03-03|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160307135117/http://www.stereocompare.com/headphones-buying-guide/#Hi%2520fidelity%2520headphones|archivedate=2016-03-07|df=}} Headphones are made in a range of different audio reproduction quality capabilities. Headsets designed for telephone use typically cannot reproduce sound with the [[high fidelity]] of expensive units designed for music listening by [[audiophile]]s. Headphones that use cables typically have either a 1/4 inch (6.35mm) or 1/8 inch (3.5mm) [[phone connector (audio)|phone jack]] for plugging the headphones into the audio source. Some stereo earbuds are wireless, using [[Bluetooth]] connectivity to transmit the audio signal by radio waves from source devices like cellphones and digital players.{{cite web |url=https://www.fastcompany.com/3055208/its-true-apple-will-drop-the-headphone-jack-to-make-the-iphone-7-slimmer-and-simpler |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-08-29 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160829052849/http://www.fastcompany.com/3055208/its-true-apple-will-drop-the-headphone-jack-to-make-the-iphone-7-slimmer-and-simpler |archivedate=2016-08-29 |df= }} Due to the spread of wireless devices in recent years headphones are increasingly used by people in public places such as sidewalks, grocery stores, and public transit. Headphones are also used by people in various professional contexts, such as [[audio engineer]]s mixing sound for live concerts or [[sound recording]]s and [[DJ]]s, who use headphones to [[cue (audio)|cue]] up the next song without the audience hearing, aircraft pilots and [[call center]] employees. The latter two types of employees use headphones with an integrated microphone. =={{anchor|history}}History== [[Image:Brandes Superior Matched Tone c. 1919-21.jpg|thumb|right|Brandes radio headphones, circa 1920]] Headphones originated from the telephone receiver earpiece, and were the only way to listen to electrical [[audio signal]]s before amplifiers were developed. The first truly successful set was developed in 1910 by [[Nathaniel Baldwin]], who made them by hand in his kitchen and sold them to the [[United States Navy]].{{cite book|url=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=uiug.30112064674325;view=1up;seq=181|title=Howeth: Chapter XI|date=1963|work=|accessdate=5 March 2018|df=}}[http://historytogo.utah.gov/salt_lake_tribune/history_matters/070801.html Utah History To Go. ''Ruin Followed Riches for a Utah Genius'' (Will Bagley for the Salt Lake Tribune, July 8, 2001)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090911070726/http://www.historytogo.utah.gov/salt_lake_tribune/history_matters/070801.html |date=September 11, 2009 }} These early headphones used [[Moving iron speaker|moving iron drivers]], with either single-ended or balanced armatures. The common single-ended type used voice coils wound around the poles of a permanent magnet, which were positioned close to a flexible steel diaphragm. The audio current through the coils varied the magnetic field of the magnet, exerting a varying force on the diaphragm, causing it to vibrate, creating sound waves. The requirement for high sensitivity meant that no damping was used, so the frequency response of the diaphragm had large peaks due to resonance, resulting in poor [[sound quality]]. These early models lacked padding, and were often uncomfortable to wear for long periods. Their [[Electrical impedance|impedance]] varied; headphones used in [[telegraph]] and telephone work had an impedance of 75 [[ohm]]s. Those used with early wireless radio had more turns of finer wire to increase sensitivity. Impedance of 1000 to 2000 ohms was common, which suited both crystal sets and [[triode]] receivers. Some very sensitive headphones, such as those manufactured by Brandes around 1919, were commonly used for early radio work. In early powered radios, the headphone was part of the [[vacuum tube]]'s [[Plate electrode|plate]] circuit and carried dangerous voltages. It was normally connected directly to the positive high voltage battery terminal, and the other battery terminal was securely grounded. The use of bare electrical connections meant that users could be shocked if they touched the bare headphone connections while adjusting an uncomfortable headset. In 1958, [[John C. Koss]], an [[audiophile]] and [[jazz musician]] from [[Milwaukee]], produced the first stereo headphones.{{cite web|title=Founded 1958 - World's First SP/3 Stereophone|url=https://www.koss.com/history/|website=koss.com|accessdate=13 September 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170913183148/https://www.koss.com/history/|archivedate=13 September 2017|df=}}{{cite web|title=Now hear this: the history of headphones|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2011/oct/30/history-of-headphones|last=Smith|first=Caspar|publisher=The Guardian|date=30 October 2011|accessdate=13 September 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170913182953/https://www.theguardian.com/business/2011/oct/30/history-of-headphones|archivedate=13 September 2017|df=}} Previously, headphones were used only by the US navy, telephone and radio operators, and individuals in similar industries. Smaller earbud type earpieces, which plugged into the user's ear canal, were first developed for [[hearing aids]]. They became widely used with [[transistor radio]]s, which commercially appeared in 1954 with the introduction of the [[Regency TR-1]]. The most popular audio device in history, the transistor radio changed listening habits, allowing people to listen to radio anywhere. The earbud uses either a moving iron driver or a [[crystal earpiece|piezoelectric crystal]] to produce sound. The 3.5 mm radio and [[Phone connector (audio)|phone connector]], which is the most commonly used in portable application today, has been used at least since the Sony EFM-117J transistor radio, which was released in 1964.{{cite web|title=Sony history 1960s|url=http://www.sony.net/Fun/design/history/1960.html|website=Sony official website|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160205195855/http://www.sony.net/Fun/design/history/1960.html|archivedate=2016-02-05|df=}}Description of 3.5mm earphone jack in described model:
{{cite web|url=http://www.worthpoint.com/worthopedia/vintage-sony-1960-efm-117j-radio-47603127|title=Vintage Sony 1960’S EFM-117J Radio|website=[[WorthPoint]]|accessdate=2016-01-25}} Its popularity was reinforced with its use on the [[Walkman]] portable tape player in 1979. == Applications == Headphones may be used with stationary [[Compact disc player|CD]] and [[DVD player]]s, [[home cinema|home theater]], [[personal computer]]s, or portable devices (e.g., [[digital audio player]]/[[MP3 player]], [[mobile phone]]). [[Cordless]] headphones are not connected to their source by a cable. Instead, they receive a [[radio]] or [[infrared]] signal encoded using a radio or infrared transmission link, such as [[frequency modulation|FM]], [[Bluetooth]] or [[Wi-Fi]]. These are powered receiver systems, of which the headphone is only a component. Cordless headphones are used with events such as a [[Silent disco]] or [[Silent Gig]]. [[File:Headphones-Sennheiser-HD555.jpg|thumb|[[Sennheiser]] HD 555 headphones, used in [[Audio Production|audio production]] environments (2007)]] In the [[professional audio]] sector, headphones are used in live situations by [[disc jockey]]s with a [[DJ mixer]], and [[sound engineer]]s for monitoring signal sources. In radio studios, [[DJ]]s use a pair of headphones when talking to the microphone while the speakers are turned off to eliminate [[acoustic feedback]] while monitoring their own voice. In studio recordings, musicians and singers use headphones to play or sing along to a backing track or band. In military applications, audio signals of many varieties are monitored using headphones. Wired headphones are attached to an audio source by a cable. The most common connectors are 6.35 mm (¼″) and 3.5 mm [[Phone connector (audio)|phone connectors]]. The larger 6.35 mm connector is more common on fixed location home or professional equipment. The 3.5 mm connector remains the most widely used connector for portable application today. Adapters are available for converting between 6.35 mm and 3.5 mm devices. == Electrical characteristics == [[Electrical characteristics of dynamic loudspeakers]] may be readily applied to headphones, because most headphones are small dynamic loudspeakers. === Impedance === Headphones are available with low or high [[Electrical impedance|impedance]] (typically measured at 1 kHz). Low-impedance headphones are in the range 16 to 32 ohms and high-impedance headphones are about 100-600 ohms. As the impedance of a pair of headphones increases, more voltage (at a given current) is required to drive it, and the loudness of the headphones for a given voltage decreases. In recent years, impedance of newer headphones has generally decreased to accommodate lower voltages available on battery powered [[CMOS]]-based portable electronics. This has resulted in headphones that can be more efficiently driven by battery-powered electronics. Consequently, newer amplifiers are based on designs with relatively low output impedance. The impedance of headphones is of concern because of the output limitations of amplifiers. A modern pair of headphones is driven by an amplifier, with lower impedance headphones presenting a larger load. Amplifiers are not ideal; they also have some output impedance that limits the amount of power they can provide. To ensure an even frequency response, adequate [[damping factor]], and undistorted sound, an amplifier should have an output impedance less than 1/8 that of the headphones it is driving (and ideally, as low as possible). If output impedance is large compared to the impedance of the headphones, significantly higher distortion is present.{{cite web |last=Siau |first=John |title=The "0-Ohm" Headphone Amplifier |url=http://www.benchmarkmedia.com/discuss/sites/default/files/Headphone-Amplifier-Performance-Part-2.pdf |accessdate=26 June 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130210012625/http://www.benchmarkmedia.com/discuss/sites/default/files/Headphone-Amplifier-Performance-Part-2.pdf |archivedate=10 February 2013 |df= }} Therefore, lower impedance headphones tend to be louder and more efficient, but also demand a more capable amplifier. Higher impedance headphones are more tolerant of amplifier limitations, but produce less volume for a given output level. Historically, many headphones had relatively high impedance, often over 500 ohms so they could operate well with high-impedance [[Valve amplifier#Operation|tube amplifiers]]. In contrast, modern transistor amplifiers can have very low output impedance, enabling lower-impedance headphones. Unfortunately, this means that older audio amplifiers or stereos often produce poor-quality output on some modern, low-impedance headphones. In this case, an external [[headphone amplifier]] may be beneficial. === Sensitivity === Sensitivity is a measure of how effectively an earpiece converts an incoming electrical signal into an audible sound. It thus indicates how loud the headphones are for a given electrical drive level. It can be measured in [[decibel]]s of [[sound pressure]] level per milli[[watt]] (dB (SPL)/mW) or decibels of sound pressure level per [[volt]] (dB (SPL) / V).{{cite web |url=http://gilmore2.chem.northwestern.edu/tech/dbohn1_tech.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-03-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110608015203/http://gilmore2.chem.northwestern.edu/tech/dbohn1_tech.htm |archivedate=2011-06-08 |df= }} Unfortunately, both definitions are widely used, often interchangeably. As the output voltage (but not power) of a headphone amplifier is essentially constant for most common headphones, dB/mW is often more useful if converted into dB/V using [[Ohm's law]]: :\mathrm{dB (SPL)}/\mathrm{V} = \mathrm{dB (SPL)}/\mathrm{mW} - 10 \cdot \log_{10}{\frac{\mathrm{Impedance}}{1000}} Alternatively, online calculators can be used.{{cite web|title=Headphone Sensitivity & Efficiency Calculator|url=http://www.jensign.com/S4/calc.html|accessdate=22 November 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141115085636/http://www.jensign.com/S4/calc.html|archivedate=15 November 2014|df=}} Once the sensitivity per volt is known, the maximum volume for a pair of headphones can be easily calculated from the maximum amplifier output voltage. For example, for a headphone with a sensitivity of 100 dB (SPL)/V, an amplifier with an output of 1 [[root mean square]] (RMS) [[voltage]] produces a maximum volume of 100 dB. Pairing high sensitivity headphones with power amplifiers can produce dangerously high volumes and damage headphones. The maximum [[sound pressure]] level is a matter of preference, with some sources recommending no higher than 110 to 120 dB. In contrast, the American [[Occupational Safety and Health Administration]] recommends an average SPL of no more than 85 dB(A) to avoid long-term hearing loss, while the [[European Union]] standard EN 50332-1:2013 recommends that volumes above 85 dB(A) include a warning, with an absolute maximum volume (defined using 40–4000 Hz noise) of no more than 100 dB to avoid accidental hearing damage.{{cite web|title=BS EN 50332 tests for headphones and earphones with portable music players|accessdate=22 November 2014|ref=http://www.isvr.co.uk/labtests/en50332.htm}} Using this standard, headphones with sensitivities of 90, 100 and 110 dB (SPL)/V should be driven by an amplifier capable of no more than 3.162, 1.0 and 0.3162 RMS volts at maximum volume setting, respectively to reduce the risk of hearing damage. The sensitivity of headphones is usually between about 80 and 125 dB/mW and usually measured at 1 kHz.{{cite web |title=Understanding Earphone/Headphone Specifications |url=http://shure.custhelp.com/app/answers/detail/a_id/2991/~/understanding-earphone-%2F-headphone-specifications |work=Shure Customer Help |publisher=Shure |accessdate=30 December 2012}} == Types == Headphone size can affect the balance between fidelity and portability. Generally, headphone form factors can be divided into four separate categories: ''circumaural (over-ear)'', ''supra-aural (on-ear)'', ''earbud'' and ''in-ear''. === Circumaural === [[Image:Headphones 1.jpg|thumb|Circumaural headphones have large pads that surround the outer ear.]] '''Circumaural headphones''' (sometimes called '''full size headphones''' or over-ear headphones) have circular or ellipsoid earpads that encompass the ears. Because these headphones completely surround the ear, circumaural headphones can be designed to fully seal against the head to attenuate external noise. Because of their size, circumaural headphones can be heavy and there are some sets that weigh over {{convert|500|g|lb|0}}. Ergonomic headband and earpad design is required to reduce discomfort resulting from weight. These are commonly used by drummers in recording. === Supra-aural === [[Image:GradoPrestige-HeadphoneArticle.jpg|thumb|A pair of supra-aural (on-ear) headphones]] '''Supra-aural headphones''' or on-ear headphones have pads that press against the ears, rather than around them. They were commonly bundled with [[personal stereo]]s during the 1980s. This type of headphone generally tends to be smaller and lighter than circumaural headphones, resulting in less attenuation of outside noise. Supra-aural headphones can also lead to discomfort due to the pressure on the ear as compared to circumaural headphones that sit around the ear. Comfort may vary due to the earcup material. === Open or closed back === Both circumaural and supra-aural headphones can be further differentiated by the type of earcups: '''Open-back''' headphones have the back of the earcups open. This leaks more sound out of the headphone and also lets more ambient sounds into the headphone, but gives a more natural or speaker-like sound, due to including sounds from the environment. '''Closed-back''' (or sealed) styles have the back of the earcups closed. They usually block some of the ambient noise. Closed-back headphones usually can produce stronger low frequencies than open-back headphones. '''Semi-open''' headphones, have a design that can be considered as a compromise between open-back headphones and closed-back headphones. Some{{Who|date=July 2015}} believe the term "semi-open" is purely there for marketing purposes. There is no exact definition for the term semi-open headphone. Where the open-back approach has hardly any measure to block sound at the outer side of the diaphragm and the closed-back approach really has a closed chamber at the outer side of the diaphragm, a semi-open headphone can have a chamber to partially block sound while letting some sound through via openings or vents. === Ear-fitting headphones === ==== Earphones ==== {{multiple image |direction=vertical | image1=Earphones BW 2011-12-10 15-49-08.JPG | alt1=2 | width1 = 170 | image2=EarPods derecho.JPG | alt3=4 | width2 = 170 | footer = Earbuds/earphones sit in the outer ear }} Earphones are very small headphones that are fitted directly in the [[outer ear]], facing but not inserted in the ear canal. Earphones are portable and convenient, but many people consider them uncomfortable.{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,1982314,00.html|title=Earbud Review: Best Headphones for Price, Hearing Safety - TIME|date=26 April 2010|work=TIME.com|accessdate=21 July 2015|first=Peter|last=Ha|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130817093143/http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,1982314,00.html|archivedate=17 August 2013|df=}} They provide hardly any acoustic isolation and leave room for ambient noise to seep in; users may turn up the volume dangerously high to compensate, at the risk of causing [[Hearing impairment|hearing loss]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ear-hearing.com/pt/re/earhearing/abstract.00003446-200412000-00001.htm|title=Output Levels of Commercially Available Portable Compact Dis... : Ear and Hearing|work=LWW|accessdate=21 July 2015}} On the other hand, they let the user be better aware of their surroundings. Since the early days of the [[transistor radio]], earphones have commonly been bundled with personal music devices. They are sold at times with foam pads for comfort. (The use of the term ''earbuds'', which has been around since at least 1984, did not hit its peak until after 2001, with the success of Apple's MP3 player.{{cite web |url=https://mobile.nytimes.com/2014/05/18/magazine/who-made-that-earbud.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2017-01-27 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170202030114/https://mobile.nytimes.com/2014/05/18/magazine/who-made-that-earbud.html |archivedate=2017-02-02 |df= }}) ==== In-ear headphones ==== {{Main article|In-ear monitor}} [[Image:InEarMonitors.jpg|thumb|upright|In-ear monitors extend into the ear canal, providing isolation from outside noise.]] In-ear headphones, also known as in-ear monitors (IEMs) or canalphones, are small headphones with similar portability to earbuds that are inserted in the [[ear canal]] itself. IEMs are higher-quality in-ear headphones and are used by [[audio engineer]]s and [[musician]]s as well as audiophiles. The outer shells of in-ear headphones are made up of a variety of materials, such as plastic, [[aluminum]], ceramic and other metal alloys. Because in-ear headphones engage the ear canal, they can be prone to sliding out, and they block out much environmental noise. Lack of sound from the environment can be a problem when sound is a necessary cue for safety or other reasons, as when walking, driving, or riding near or in vehicular traffic.{{cite web|title=Headphones as a Driving Distraction|url=https://www.rospa.com/rospaweb/docs/advice-services/road-safety/drivers/headphones-as-a-driver-distraction.pdf|publisher=The Royal Society for the Prevention of Accidents|format=pdf|accessdate=14 September 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170915023105/https://www.rospa.com/rospaweb/docs/advice-services/road-safety/drivers/headphones-as-a-driver-distraction.pdf|archivedate=15 September 2017|df=}} Generic or custom-fitting ear canal plugs are made from [[silicone]] rubber, [[elastomer]], or foam. Custom in-ear headphones use castings of the ear canal to create custom-molded plugs that provide added comfort and noise isolation. ==== Mixed fitting pivoting earphones ==== This type combines advantages of earbuds and in-ear headphones – depending on the environment and requirements of the user, they provide passive noise reduction for quality mode (conversation or active music listening) or they give control over the sound environment around user in comfort mode (stand by or background voice/music listening).{{cn|date=August 2017}} === Headset === {{Main article|Headset (audio)}} [[File:Plantronics headset.jpg|thumb|left|A typical example of a headset used for [[voice chat]]s]] A headset is a headphone combined with a [[microphone]]. Headsets provide the equivalent functionality of a telephone handset with hands-free operation. Among applications for headsets, besides telephone use, are aviation, theatre or television studio intercom systems, and console or PC gaming. Headsets are made with either a single-earpiece (mono) or a double-earpiece (mono to both ears or stereo). The microphone arm of headsets is either an external microphone type where the microphone is held in front of the user's mouth, or a voicetube type where the microphone is housed in the earpiece and speech reaches it by means of a hollow tube. ==== Telephone headsets ==== [[File:Se bluetooth headset.jpg|thumb|[[Sony Ericsson]] Cordless bluetooth headset]] Telephone headsets connect to a [[fixed-line]] telephone system. A telephone headset functions by replacing the [[handset]] of a telephone. Headsets for standard corded telephones are fitted with a standard [[4P4C]] commonly called an RJ-9 connector. Headsets are also available with 2.5 mm jack sockets for many DECT phones and other applications. Cordless [[bluetooth]] headsets are available, and often used with [[mobile telephone]]s. Headsets are widely used for telephone-intensive jobs, in particular by [[call centre]] workers. They are also used by anyone wishing to hold telephone conversations with both hands free. For older models of telephones, the headset microphone [[electrical impedance|impedance]] is different from that of the original handset, requiring a telephone amplifier for the telephone headset. A telephone amplifier provides basic pin-alignment similar to a telephone headset adaptor, but it also offers sound [[amplifier|amplification]] for the microphone as well as the loudspeakers. Most models of telephone amplifiers offer volume control for loudspeaker as well as microphone, mute function and switching between headset and handset. Telephone amplifiers are powered by batteries or [[AC adaptor]]s. == Ambient noise reduction == [[File:In-ears-earphones.png|thumb|left|In-ears are among those good for noise isolation]] Unwanted sound from the environment can be reduced by excluding sound from the ear by passive noise isolation, or, often in conjunction with isolation, by active [[Noise-cancelling headphones|noise cancellation]]. Passive noise isolation is essentially using the body of the earphone, either over or in the ear, as a passive earplug that simply blocks out sound. The headphone types that provide most attenuation are in-ear canal headphones and closed-back headphones, both circumaural and supra aural. Open-back and earbud headphones provide some passive noise isolation, but much less than the others. Typical closed-back headphones block 8 to 12 dB, and in-ears anywhere from 10 to 15 dB. Some models have been specifically designed for drummers to facilitate the drummer monitoring the recorded sound while reducing sound directly from the drums as much as possible. Such headphones claim to reduce ambient noise by around 25 dB. Active noise-cancelling headphones use a microphone, amplifier, and speaker to pick up, amplify, and play ambient noise in phase-reversed form; this to some extent cancels out unwanted noise from the environment without affecting the desired sound source, which is not picked up and reversed by the microphone. They require a power source, usually a battery, to drive their circuitry. Active noise cancelling headphones can attenuate ambient noise by 20 dB or more, but the active circuitry is mainly effective on constant sounds and at lower frequencies, rather than sharp sounds and voices. Some noise cancelling headphones are designed mainly to reduce low-frequency engine and travel noise in aircraft, trains, and automobiles, and are less effective in environments with other types of noise. == Transducer technology == Headphones use various types of [[transducer]] to convert electrical signals to sound. === Moving-coil === [[Image:Headphone-transducer.jpg|thumb|right|A typical moving-coil headphone transducer]] The [[Loudspeaker|moving coil driver]], more commonly referred to as a "dynamic" driver is the most common type used in headphones. It consists of a stationary [[magnet]] element affixed to the frame of the headphone, which sets up a static magnetic field. The magnet in headphones is typically composed of [[Ferrite (magnet)|ferrite]] or [[Neodymium magnet|neodymium]]. A [[voice coil]], a light coil of wire, is suspended in the magnetic field of the magnet, attached to a diaphragm, typically fabricated from lightweight, high-stiffness-to-mass-ratio cellulose, polymer, carbon material, paper or the like. When the varying current of an [[audio signal]] is passed through the coil, it creates a varying magnetic field that reacts against the static magnetic field, exerting a varying force on the coil causing it and the attached diaphragm to vibrate. The vibrating diaphragm pushes on the air to produce [[sound wave]]s. === Electrostatic === [[Image:Es spk.gif|thumb|right|Electrostatic loudspeaker diagram]] Electrostatic drivers consist of a thin, electrically charged diaphragm, typically a coated [[PET film (biaxially oriented)|PET film]] membrane, suspended between two perforated metal plates (electrodes). The electrical sound signal is applied to the electrodes creating an electrical field; depending on the polarity of this field, the diaphragm is drawn towards one of the plates. Air is forced through the perforations; combined with a continuously changing electrical signal driving the membrane, a sound wave is generated. Electrostatic headphones are usually more expensive than moving-coil ones, and are comparatively uncommon. In addition, a special amplifier is required to amplify the signal to deflect the membrane, which often requires electrical potentials in the range of 100 to 1000 volts. Due to the extremely thin and light diaphragm membrane, often only a few micrometers thick, and the complete absence of moving metalwork, the frequency response of electrostatic headphones usually extends well above the audible limit of approximately 20 kHz. The high frequency response means that the low midband distortion level is maintained to the top of the audible frequency band, which is generally not the case with moving coil drivers. Also, the frequency response peakiness regularly seen in the high frequency region with moving coil drivers is absent. Well-designed electrostatic headphones can produce significantly better sound quality than other types.{{citation needed|reason=Such broad claims need sources|date=May 2015}} Electrostatic headphones require a voltage source generating 100 V to over 1 kV, and are on the user's head. Since the invention of insulators, there's no actual danger. They do not need to deliver significant [[electric current]], which further limits the electrical hazard to the wearer in case of fault. === Electret === An [[electret]] driver functions along the same electromechanical means as an electrostatic driver. However the electret driver has a permanent charge built into it, whereas electrostatics have the charge applied to the driver by an external generator. Electret and electrostatic headphones are relatively uncommon. Original electrets were also typically cheaper and lower in technical capability and fidelity than electrostatics. Patent applications from 2009-2013 have been approved that show by using different materials, i.e. a "Fluorinated cyclic olefin electret film", Frequency response chart readings can reach 50 kHz at 100db. When these new improved electrets are combined with a traditional dome headphone driver, headphones can be produced that are recognised by the Japan Audio Society as worthy of joining the Hi Res Audio program. US patents 8,559,660 B2. 7,732,547 B2.7,879,446 B2.7,498,699 B2. ===Orthodynamic=== Orthodynamic (also known as Planar Magnetic) headphones use similar technology to electrostatic headphones, with some fundamental differences. They operate similarly to [[Loudspeaker#Ribbon and planar magnetic loudspeakers|Planar Magnetic Loudspeakers]]. An orthodynamic driver consists of a relatively large membrane that contains an embedded wire pattern. This membrane is suspended between two sets of permanent, oppositely aligned, magnets. A current passed through the wires embedded in the membrane produces a magnetic field that reacts with the field of the permanent magnets to induce movement in the membrane, which produces sound. === Balanced armature === [[Image:Bal Arm.JPG|thumb|left|Balanced armature transducer with armature balanced and exerting no force on diaphragm]] A balanced armature is a sound transducer design primarily intended to increase the electrical efficiency of the element by eliminating the stress on the diaphragm characteristic of many other magnetic transducer systems. As shown schematically in the first diagram, it consists of a moving magnetic armature that is pivoted so it can move in the field of the permanent magnet. When precisely centered in the magnetic field there is no net force on the armature, hence the term 'balanced.' As illustrated in the second diagram, when there is [[electric current]] through the coil, it [[Electromagnet|magnetizes]] the armature one way or the other, causing it to rotate slightly one way or the other about the pivot thus moving the [[Diaphragm (acoustics)|diaphragm]] to make [[sound]]. [[Image:JH16 Balanced Armatures.jpg|upright|thumb|A custom in-ear monitor which uses 8 balanced armatures in a triple crossover configuration (4 low/2 mid/2 high). Headphone designs often use multiple balanced armatures to provide a higher fidelity sound.]] The design is not mechanically stable; a slight imbalance makes the armature stick to one pole of the magnet. A fairly stiff restoring force is required to hold the armature in the 'balance' position. Although this reduces its efficiency, this design can still produce more sound from less power than any other{{Clarify|date=January 2014|reason=isn't more sound from less power the definition of high efficiency?}}. Popularized in the 1920s as Baldwin Mica Diaphragm radio headphones, balanced armature transducers were refined during [[World War II]] for use in military [[sound powered telephone]]s. Some of these achieved astonishing electro-acoustic conversion efficiencies, in the range of 20% to 40%, for narrow bandwidth voice signals. Today they are typically used only in in-ear headphones and hearing aids, where their high efficiency and diminutive size is a major advantage. Tyll Hertsens. [http://www.innerfidelity.com/content/how-balanced-armature-receiversdrivers-work "How Balanced Armature Receivers/Drivers Work"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150914044126/http://www.innerfidelity.com/content/how-balanced-armature-receiversdrivers-work |date=2015-09-14 }}. 2014. They generally are limited at the extremes of the hearing spectrum (e.g. below 20 Hz and above 16 kHz) and require a better seal than other types of drivers to deliver their full potential. Higher-end models may employ multiple armature drivers, dividing the frequency ranges between them using a passive crossover network. A few combine an armature driver with a small moving-coil driver for increased bass output. The earliest loudspeakers for radio receivers used balanced armature drivers for their cones.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5IMSAQAAMAAJ&q=earliest+loudspeakers+used+balanced+armature+drivers+for+their+cones.&dq=earliest+loudspeakers+used+balanced+armature+drivers+for+their+cones.&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjmp-GsiOTXAhWhwFQKHV8fD80Q6AEILjAB|title=A History of Engineering and Science in the Bell System: The early years (1875-1925)|last=Joel|first=Amos E.|last2=Laboratories|first2=Bell Telephone|last3=Schindler|first3=G. E.|date=1975|publisher=The Laboratories|language=en}} === Thermoacoustic technology === The thermoacoustic effect generates sound from the audio frequency Joule heating of the conductor, an effect that is not magnetic and does not vibrate the speaker. In 2013 a carbon nanotube thin-yarn earphone based on the thermoacoustic mechanism was demonstrated by a research group in Tsinghua University.{{cite journal |author1=Yang Wei |author2=Xiaoyang Lin |author3=Kaili Jiang |author4=Peng Liu |author5=Qunqing Li |author6=Shoushan Fan |title=Thermoacoustic Chips with Carbon Nanotube Thin Yarn Arrays. |journal=Nano Letters |year=2013 |doi=10.1021/nl402408j |url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1021/nl402408j |pmid=24041369 |volume=13 |issue=10 |pages=4795–801}} The as-produced CNT thin yarn earphone has a working element called CNT thin yarn thermoacoustic chip. Such a chip is composed of a layer of CNT thin yarn array supported by the silicon wafer, and periodic grooves with certain depth are made on the wafer by micro-fabrication methods to suppress the heat leakage from the CNT yarn to the substrate.{{citation needed|date=May 2015}} === Other transducer technologies === Transducer technologies employed much less commonly for headphones include the [[Oskar Heil|Heil]] [[Air Motion Transformer]] (AMT); Piezoelectric film; Ribbon planar magnetic; Magnetostriction and [[Plasma speaker|Plasma-ionisation]]. The first [[Air Motion Transformer|Heil AMT]] headphone was marketed by [[ESS Laboratories]] and was essentially an ESS AMT tweeter from one of the company's speakers being driven at full range. Since the turn of the century, only [[Precide]] of Switzerland have manufactured an AMT headphone. Piezoelectric film headphones were first developed by Pioneer, their two models used a flat sheet of film that limited the maximum volume of air movement. Currently, TakeT produces a piezoelectric film headphone shaped similarly to an AMT transducer but, which like the Precide driver, has a variation in the size of transducer folds over the diaphragm. It additionally incorporates a two way design by its inclusion of a dedicated tweeter/supertweeter panel. The folded shape of a diaphragm allows a transducer with a larger surface area to fit within smaller space constraints. This increases the total volume of air that can be moved on each excursion of the transducer given that radiating area. [[Magnetostriction]] headphones, sometimes sold under the label ''Bonephones'', work by vibrating against the side of head, transmitting sound via [[bone conduction]]. This is particularly helpful in situations where the ears must be unobstructed, or for people who are [[deaf]] for reasons that don't affect the nervous apparatus of [[Hearing (sense)|hearing]]. Magnetostriction headphones though, are limited in their fidelity compared to conventional headphones that rely on the normal workings of the ear. Additionally, in the early 1990s, a French company called Plasmasonics tried to market a plasma-ionisation headphone. There are no known functioning examples left. == Benefits and limitations == [[Image:Sony MDR-V6 headphones.jpg|thumb|Two [[Sony MDR-V6]] headphones, one folded for travel]] Headphones can prevent other people from hearing the sound, either for [[privacy]] or to prevent disturbing others, as in listening in a public [[library]]. They can also provide a level of sound fidelity greater than loudspeakers of similar cost. Part of their ability to do so comes from the lack of any need to perform room correction treatments with headphones. High-quality headphones can have an extremely flat low-frequency response down to 20 Hz within 3 dB. While a loudspeaker must use a relatively large (often 15" or 18") [[speaker driver]] to reproduce low frequencies, headphones can accurately reproduce bass and sub-bass frequencies with speaker drivers only 40-50 millimeters wide (or much smaller, as is the case with [[in-ear monitor]] headphones). Headphones' impressive low-frequency performance is possible because they are so much closer to the ear that they only need to move relatively small volumes of air. Marketed claims such as 'frequency response 4 Hz to 20 kHz' are usually overstatements; the product's response at frequencies lower than 20 Hz is typically very small.[http://reviews.cnet.com/4520-7612_7-6322607-4.html cnet reviews: Headphone Buying Guide] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110820010315/http://reviews.cnet.com/4520-7612_7-6322607-4.html |date=2011-08-20 }} "Even the flimsiest, cheap headphones routinely boast extremely low bass-response performance—15 or 20Hz—but almost always sound lightweight and bright." Headphones are also useful for [[video game]]s that use 3D positional audio processing algorithms, as they allow players to better judge the position of an off-screen sound source (such as the footsteps of an opponent or their gun fire). Although modern headphones have been particularly widely sold and used for listening to [[Stereophonic sound|stereo recordings]] since the release of the [[Walkman]], there is subjective debate regarding the nature of their reproduction of stereo sound. Stereo recordings represent the position of horizontal depth cues (stereo separation) via volume and phase differences of the sound in question between the two channels. When the sounds from two speakers mix, they create the [[phase (waves)|phase]] difference the brain uses to locate direction. Through most headphones, because the right and left channels do not combine in this manner, the illusion of the phantom center can be perceived as lost. Hard [[Panning (audio)|panned]] sounds are also heard only in one ear rather than from one side. [[Binaural recording]]s use a different microphone technique to encode direction directly as phase, with very little amplitude difference below 2 kHz, often using a [[dummy head recording|dummy head]]. They can produce a surprisingly lifelike spatial impression through headphones. Commercial recordings almost always use stereo recording, rather than binaural, because loudspeaker listening is more common than headphone listening. It is possible to change the spatial effects of stereo sound on headphones, to better approximate the presentation of speaker reproduction, by using frequency-dependent cross-feed between the channels. Headsets can have [[ergonomic]] benefits over traditional telephone handsets. They allow [[call centre|call center]] agents to maintain better [[human position|posture]] without needing to hand-hold a [[transceiver#Telephony|handset]] or tilt their head sideways to cradle it.[http://www.osha.gov/SLTC/etools/computerworkstations/checklist.html United States Department of Labor. Occupational Safety & Health Administration. ''Computer Workstation. Checklist.''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090202190631/http://osha.gov/SLTC/etools/computerworkstations/checklist.html |date=2009-02-02 }} Accessed February 2, 2009. == Dangers and volume solutions == {{See also|Automatic volume limiter}} [[File:Consumer Reports - product testing - headphones in anechoic chamber.tif|thumb|Product testing - headphones in an [[anechoic chamber]]]] Using headphones at a sufficiently high [[volume]] level may cause temporary or permanent [[hearing impairment]] or [[deafness]]. The headphone volume often has to compete with the [[background noise]], especially in loud places such as subway stations, aircraft, and large crowds. Extended periods of exposure to high sound pressure levels created by headphones at high volume settings may be damaging;{{cite web|url=http://www.asha.org/public/hearing/disorders/causes_adults.htm|title=Causes of Hearing Loss in Adults|work=asha.org|accessdate=21 July 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nidcd.nih.gov/health/hearing/noise.asp|title=Noise-Induced Hearing Loss|work=nih.gov|accessdate=21 July 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160509092930/https://www.nidcd.nih.gov/health/hearing/noise.asp|archivedate=9 May 2016|df=}} however, one hearing expert found that "fewer than 5% of users select volume levels and listen frequently enough to risk hearing loss."{{cite web|url=http://www.audiologyonline.com/articles/article_detail.asp?article_id=221|title=Five Myths in Assessing the Effects of Noise on Hearing|author=William W. Clark|work=AudiologyOnline|accessdate=21 July 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120924203231/http://www.audiologyonline.com/articles/article_detail.asp?article_id=221|archivedate=24 September 2012|df=}} Some manufacturers of portable music devices have attempted to introduce safety circuitry that limited output volume or warned the user when dangerous volume was being used, but the concept has been rejected by most of the buying public, which favors the personal choice of high volume. [[Koss Corporation|Koss]] introduced the "Safelite" line of cassette players in 1983 with such a warning light. The line was discontinued two years later for lack of interest. The government of [[France]] has imposed a limit on all music players sold in the country:[http://europa.eu/rapid/pressReleasesAction.do?reference=IP/09/1364&format=HTML&aged=0&language=EN&guiLanguage=en Europa.eu. ''Consumers: EU acts to limit health risks from exposure to noise from personal music players ''] they must not be capable of producing more than 100dBA (the threshold of hearing damage during extended listening is 80 dB, and the threshold of pain, or theoretically of immediate hearing loss, is 130 dB).{{cite web |url=http://www.lookformedical.com/search.php?lang=1&q=Cochlea&src=faq&from=8 |title=Medical Information Search (Cochlea • FAQ) |publisher=Lookformedical.com |accessdate=2013-09-06 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131212112326/http://www.lookformedical.com/search.php?lang=1&q=Cochlea&src=faq&from=8 |archivedate=2013-12-12 |df= }} Motorcycle and other power-sport riders benefit by wearing foam earplugs when legal to do so to avoid excessive road, engine, and wind noise, but their ability to hear music and [[intercom]] speech is actually enhanced when doing so. The ear can normally detect 1-billionth of an atmosphere of sound pressure level,A standard [[threshold of hearing]] at 1000 [[Hertz|Hz]] for the human ear is 2 x 10−5 [[Pascal (unit)|Pa]] ({{cite web |last=Marsh |first=Andrew |title=Human Ear and Hearing |url=http://www.kemt.fei.tuke.sk/Predmety/KEMT320_EA/_web/Online_Course_on_Acoustics/hearing.html |work=Online Course on Acoustics |publisher=The School of Architecture and Fine Arts, The University of Western Australia |accessdate=23 August 2010 |year=1999 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100721180215/http://www.kemt.fei.tuke.sk/Predmety/KEMT320_EA/_web/Online_Course_on_Acoustics/hearing.html |archivedate=21 July 2010 |df= }}); Standard [[atmospheric pressure]] is 101,325 Pa. 2 x 10−5 / 100,000 = 0.2 x 10−9, a ratio of less than a billionth. hence it is incredibly sensitive. At very high sound pressure levels, muscles in the ear tighten the tympanic membrane and this leads to a small change in the geometry of the ossicles and stirrup that results in lower transfer of force to the oval window of the inner ear (the [[acoustic reflex]]).{{cite web|url=http://hyperphysics.phy-astr.gsu.edu/Hbase/sound/protect.html#c1|title=The Ear's Protective Mechanisms|work=gsu.edu|accessdate=21 July 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150503013758/http://hyperphysics.phy-astr.gsu.edu/hbase/sound/protect.html#c1|archivedate=3 May 2015|df=}} The risk of hearing damage also depends on the exposure time. The higher the volume, the faster hearing loss occurs. According to [[Occupational Safety and Health Administration|OSHA]] work safety guidelines, workers should be exposed to 90dBA noise for a maximum of 8 hours to avoid hearing loss. An increase to just 95dBA cuts the safe exposure to only 4 hours. But there is little specific consensus on the safe level of exposure. [[National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health|NIOSH]] has an 8-hour recommended exposure limit set to 85dBA. Additionally, an increase to 93dBA instead of 95dBA halves the safe exposure time to 4 hours.{{Cite web|url=https://www.osha.gov/Publications/laboratory/OSHAfactsheet-laboratory-safety-noise.pdf|title=OSHA Fact Sheet Laboratory Safety Noise|last=|first=|date=|website=OSHA.gov|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170829231722/https://www.osha.gov/Publications/laboratory/OSHAfactsheet-laboratory-safety-noise.pdf|archive-date=2017-08-29|dead-url=no|access-date=|df=}} Some studies have found that people are more likely to raise volumes to unsafe levels while performing strenuous exercise.{{cite web|title=Can Loud Noise during Exercise Damage my Hearing?|url=http://www.healthyhearing.com/content/faqs/Hearing-loss/Causes/31070-Loud-noise-during-exercise|website=Healthy Hearing|accessdate=8 November 2014|location=Item 4|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141109002409/http://www.healthyhearing.com/content/faqs/Hearing-loss/Causes/31070-Loud-noise-during-exercise|archivedate=9 November 2014|df=}} A Finnish studyAiro, Erkko; J. Pekkarinen; P. Olkinuora. "Listening to music with earphones: an assessment of noise exposure," ''Acustica–Acta Acustica'', pp. 82, 885–894. (1996) recommended that exercisers should set their headphone volumes to half of their normal loudness and only use them for half an hour. Noise cancelling headphones can be considered dangerous because of a lack of awareness the listener may have with their environment. Noise cancelling headphones are so effective that a person may not be able to hear oncoming traffic or pay attention to people around them. There is also a general danger that music in headphones can distract the listener and lead to dangerous situations.{{cite web |url=http://abcnews.go.com/Health/w_DietAndFitnessNews/deaf-danger-perils-earbuds-exercising/story?id=13925714#.UcMJhufVDoI |title=Deaf to Danger: The Perils of Earbuds |last1=Greenfield |first1=Paige |date=25 June 2011 |website=ABC News |accessdate=20 June 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131214122323/http://abcnews.go.com/Health/w_DietAndFitnessNews/deaf-danger-perils-earbuds-exercising/story?id=13925714#.UcMJhufVDoI |archivedate=14 December 2013 |df= }} The usual way of limiting sound volume on devices driving headphones is by limiting output power. This has the additional undesirable effect of being dependent of the efficiency of the headphones; a device producing the maximum allowed power may not produce adequate volume when paired with low-efficiency, high-impedance equipment, while the same amount of power can reach dangerous levels with very efficient earphones. == See also == * [[Bone conduction]] * [[Digital audio player]] * [[wikt:earpad|Earpad]] * [[Headphone amplifier]] * [[In-ear monitor]] * [[List of headphone manufacturers]] * [[Noise-cancelling headphones]] == References == {{reflist|30em}} == External links == {{commons|Headphones}} {{Wiktionary|headphone|earphone|earpiece|stereophone|canalphones|earbud}} {{Music technology}} [[Category:Headphones| ]] [[Category:Headgear|Phones]] [[Category:Audio engineering]] [[Category:Consumer electronics]] [[Category:Loudspeakers]] [[Category:Transducers]] [[Category:Audiovisual introductions in 1910]]

Rescuing 9 sources and tagging 1 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10)
revision.text:
{{Infobox storm | name = January 2016 United States blizzard | image = January 2016 United States winter storm 2016-01-23 0715Z (alternate).jpg | alt = | caption = The intensifying extratropical cyclone responsible for the blizzard over the [[Northeastern United States]], at 2:15 a.m. [[Eastern Time Zone|EST]] (07:15 [[Coordinated Universal Time|UTC]]) on January 23, 2016. | type = [[Extratropical cyclone]]
[[Nor'easter]]
[[Winter storm]]
[[Ice storm]]
[[Blizzard]] | formed = {{start date|2016|01|19}} | dissipated = {{start date|2016|01|29}} | RSI = 20.14 | lowest pressure = 983 | lowest temperature = | tornadoes = 6 on January 21 | fujitascale = EF2 | tornado duration = 2 hours, 42 minutes | highest winds = {{convert|57|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} at [[Assateague Island]], [[Maryland]] sustained | gusts = {{convert|85|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} | maximum snow = Snow – {{convert|42|in|cm}} on [[Glengary, West Virginia|Glengary]], [[West Virginia]]
Ice – At least {{convert|0.75|in|mm|abbr=on}} in western [[North Carolina]] | power outages = 631,000+ people affected | total fatalities = 55 fatalities | damages = $500 million – $3 billion in economic losses | affected = [[Pacific Northwest]], [[Great Plains]], [[South Central United States]], [[Eastern United States]] (especially the [[Mid-Atlantic states]]), [[Atlantic Canada]], [[British Isles]], [[Finland]] | current advisories = | enhanced = yes | notes = Part of the '''[[2015–16 North American winter]]''' }} The '''January 2016 United States blizzard''' was a crippling and historic [[blizzard]] that produced up to 3 ft (91 cm) of snow in parts of the [[Mid-Atlantic states|Mid-Atlantic]] and [[Northeastern United States|Northeast]] United States from January 22 to January 24, 2016. Evolving from a [[shortwave trough]] that formed in the Pacific Northwest on January 19, the system consolidated into a defined [[low-pressure area]] on January 21 over [[Texas]]. Regarding it as a "potentially historic blizzard", [[meteorologist]]s indicated the storm could produce more than {{convert|2|ft|cm|abbr=on}} of snow across a wide swath of the Mid-Atlantic region and could "paralyze the eastern third of the nation".{{cite news|newspaper=[[Chicago Tribune]]|date=January 21, 2016|accessdate=January 22, 2016|title= Potentially historic blizzard looms over D.C., more than 2 feet of snow projected |url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/nationworld/ct-east-coast-snowstorm-20160121-story.html|location=Chicago, Illinois}}{{cite news|author=Angela Fritz|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|date=January 22, 2016|accessdate=January 22, 2016|title=Eastern Seaboard braces for potentially historic winter storm|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/capital-weather-gang/wp/2016/01/21/severe-winter-storm-will-be-multiple-threat-event-on-the-eastern-seaboard/|location=Washington, D.C.}} Winter weather expert [[Paul Kocin]] described the blizzard as "kind of a top-10 snowstorm".{{cite web|author=Sean Breslin|publisher=[[The Weather Channel]]|date=January 26, 2016|accessdate=January 26, 2016|title=Winter Storm Jonas: At Least 48 Dead; Roof Collapses Reported; D.C. Remains Shut Down|url=http://www.weather.com/storms/winter/news/winter-storm-jonas-impacts-news|location=Atlanta, Georgia}} On January 20–22, the governors of eleven states and the mayor of [[Washington, D.C.]] declared a state of emergency in anticipation of significant snowfall and [[blizzard]] conditions. Approximately 103 million people were affected by the storm, with 33 million people under [[blizzard warning]]s. More than 13,000 flights were cancelled in relation to the storm, with effects rippling internationally. Thousands of [[National Guard of the United States|National Guardsmen]] were placed on standby and states deployed millions of gallons of [[brine]] and thousands of tons of [[road salt]] to lessen the storm's effect on roadways. A travel ban was instituted for [[New York City]] and [[Newark, New Jersey]] for January 23–24. The storm was given various unofficial names, including ''Winter Storm Jonas'', ''Blizzard of 2016'' and ''Snowzilla''. Seven states observed snowfall in excess of {{convert|30|in|cm|abbr=on}}, with accumulations peaking at {{convert|42|in|cm|abbr=on}} in [[Glengary, West Virginia|Glengary]], West Virginia. Ice- and snow-covered roads led to hundreds of incidents across the affected region, several of which resulted in deaths and injuries. At least 55 people were killed in storm-related incidents: 12 in Virginia, 9 in Pennsylvania, 6 in New Jersey, 6 in New York, 6 in North Carolina, 4 in South Carolina, 3 in Maryland, 3 in Washington, D.C., 1 in Arkansas, 1 in Delaware, 1 in Georgia, 1 in Kentucky, 1 in Massachusetts, and 1 in Ohio. Total economic losses are estimated between $500 million and $3 billion. The storm ranked as a Category 5 "extreme" event for the Northeast on the [[Regional Snowfall Index]], and a Category 4 for the Southeast. It is the most recent winter storm to [[List of Regional Snowfall Index Category 5 winter storms|rank as a Category 5]], and the first to do so since the [[January 31 – February 2, 2011 North American blizzard|2011 Groundhog Day Blizzard]]. ==Preceding storm== A relatively minor storm ahead of the blizzard, similar to an [[Alberta clipper]], caught numerous drivers off-guard, producing a brief period of heavy snow during [[rush hour]] in the Mid-Atlantic region on January 20.{{cite news|work=[[WRAL-TV]]|publisher=[[CBS]]|date=January 21, 2016|accessdate=January 21, 2016|title=The Latest: Snow blamed for 2 North Carolina traffic deaths|url=http://www.wral.com/forecasters-sweat-multiple-scenarios-for-north-carolina/15256529/|location=Raleigh, North Carolina|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160122165636/http://www.wral.com/forecasters-sweat-multiple-scenarios-for-north-carolina/15256529/#|archive-date=2016-01-22|dead-url=yes|df=}} Although only {{convert|1|in|cm|abbr=on}} of snow fell in [[Washington, D.C.]], roadways were not treated; any snow that melted on roads quickly froze into [[black ice]], rendering them impassable. Some referred to the event as "Carmageddon 2.0". Portions of [[Interstate 95]] and [[Interstate 495 (Capital Beltway)|Interstate 495]] in Virginia and Maryland (especially on the [[Woodrow Wilson Bridge]]), as well as [[Interstate 270 (Maryland)|Interstate 270]], were brought to a standstill through the early hours of January 21.{{cite news|work=[[WTTG]]|publisher=[[21st Century Fox]]|date=January 21, 2016|accessdate=January 21, 2016|title=Carmageddon 2.0: DC's ride home from hell in 1 inch of snow|url=http://www.fox5dc.com/weather/78028676-story|location=Washington, D.C.}} [[Virginia State Police]] responded to 767 accidents and 392 reports of disabled vehicles. The [[Virginia Department of Transportation]] mobilized 115 salt trucks to clear roads. A man was killed after being struck by a snow plow in [[Beltsville, Maryland]]. Washington, D.C. Mayor [[Muriel Bowser]] issued an apology for inadequate preparations in the wake of the storm on January 22. Vehicles in Maryland became stranded, with some residents abandoning their cars altogether.{{cite news|author=Tom Liddy|publisher=[[ABC News]]|date=January 21, 2016|accessdate=January 21, 2016|title=Slick Roads Spark More Than 100 Accidents, Strand 'Hundreds' in DC Area|url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/slick-roads-spark-100-accidents-strand-hundreds-dc/story?id=36412078}} Georgia Governor [[Nathan Deal]] issued a [[state of emergency]] for northern counties on January 19, ensuring areas were better prepared than during a [[January 2014 Gulf Coast winter storm|similar storm in 2014]].{{cite news|work=[[WSB-TV]]|publisher=[[American Broadcasting Company]]|date=January 19, 2016|accessdate=January 21, 2016|title=Officials say state is ready for winter weather|url=http://www.wsbtv.com/news/news/local/officials-say-state-ready-winter-weather/np7zg/|location=Atlanta, Georgia|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160122211850/http://www.wsbtv.com/news/news/local/officials-say-state-ready-winter-weather/np7zg/#|archive-date=2016-01-22|dead-url=yes|df=}} Icy conditions prompted road closures in northern Georgia, including portions of [[Interstate 75 in Georgia|Interstate 75]]; several crashes resulted from the dangerous conditions.{{cite news|work=[[WSB-TV]]|publisher=[[American Broadcasting Company]]|date=January 20, 2016|accessdate=January 21, 2016|title=Icy conditions reported on Georgia roads|url=http://www.wsbtv.com/news/news/local/ice-reported-georgia-roads/np8Fz/|location=Ringgold, Georgia|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160122110724/http://www.wsbtv.com/news/news/local/ice-reported-georgia-roads/np8Fz/#|archive-date=2016-01-22|dead-url=yes|df=}} Similar conditions affected Tennessee and Kentucky; schools closed on account of dangerous roads.{{cite news|work=[[WTVF]]|publisher=[[E. W. Scripps Company]]|date=January 20, 2016|accessdate=January 21, 2016|title=Middle TN, Southern KY Waking Up To Snow, Ice|url=http://www.newschannel5.com/news/local-news/middle-tn-southern-ky-waking-up-to-snow|location=Nashville, Tennessee|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160122092445/http://www.newschannel5.com/news/local-news/middle-tn-southern-ky-waking-up-to-snow#|archive-date=2016-01-22|dead-url=yes|df=}} One person died and another was injured in an accident in [[Knox County, Tennessee|Knox County]] after speeding on slippery roads.{{cite news|work=[[WATE-TV]]|publisher=[[Media General]]|date=January 20, 2016|accessdate=January 21, 2016|title=Knox County sheriff: 1 dead, 1 injured after speeding car slides off road|url=http://wate.com/2016/01/20/injuries-reported-in-crash-on-snowy-knox-county-road/|location=Knoxville, Tennessee}} Two deaths resulted from snow-related car accidents in North Carolina. Another person died, and two others were injured, when a car collided with a salt truck in [[Whitley County, Kentucky]].{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|work=[[WJLA-TV]]|publisher=[[Sinclair Broadcast Group]]|date=January 21, 2016|accessdate=January 22, 2016|title=At least 4 killed in snowstorm-related deaths in Ky., N.C., Tenn.|url=http://wjla.com/weather/at-least-4-killed-in-snowstorm-related-deaths-in-ky-nc-tenn|location=Washington, D.C.}} ==Meteorological history== {{Multiple image |direction=vertical |align=left |width=250 |image1=January 2016 United States winter storm 2016-01-22 0230Z.png |caption1=The developing storm system at 9:30 p.m. EST on January 21 (02:30 UTC, January 22), over the southern United States |image2=Blizzard2016LowTracks.png |caption2=WPC forecast graphic depicting the formation of the dominant low pressure of the blizzard on January 22. }} The development of the winter storm was anticipated by forecasters for at least a week.{{cite web|author=Paul Kocin |title=Probabilistic Heavy Snow and Icing Discussion: 429 PM EST Thu Jan 21 2016 |date=January 21, 2016 |publisher=Weather Prediction Center |accessdate=January 21, 2016 |url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/discussions/hpcdiscussions.php?disc=qpfhsd |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6eiL8kT8z?url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/discussions/hpcdiscussions.php?disc=qpfhsd |archivedate=January 22, 2016 |df= }} It originated in a [[shortwave trough]]—a weather disturbance in the upper atmosphere—that came ashore at the [[Pacific Northwest]] on January 19.{{cite web|author=Frank Pereira |title=Short Range Forecast Discussion: 310 AM EST Wed Jan 20 2016 |date=January 20, 2016 |publisher=Weather Prediction Center |accessdate=January 21, 2016 |url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/discussions/hpcdiscussions.php?disc%3Dpmdspd%26version%3D3%26fmt%3Dreg |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/6eiKJTVRc?url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/discussions/hpcdiscussions.php?disc=pmdspd&version=3&fmt=reg |dead-url=yes |archive-date=January 22, 2016 |df= }} The trough strengthened as it moved southeastward through the [[Great Plains]],{{cite web|author=Brendon Rubin-Oster |title=Short Range Forecast Discussion: 321 AM EST Thu Jan 21 2016 |date=January 21, 2016 |publisher=Weather Prediction Center |accessdate=January 21, 2016 |url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/discussions/hpcdiscussions.php?disc%3Dpmdspd%26version%3D1%26fmt%3Dreg |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/6eiKX6TXT?url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/discussions/hpcdiscussions.php?disc=pmdspd&version=1&fmt=reg |dead-url=yes |archive-date=January 22, 2016 |df= }} and on January 21 it spawned a weak [[low-pressure area]] over central [[Texas]].{{cite web|author1=Patrick Burke |author2=Brian Hurley |title=Quantitative Precipitation Forecast Discussion: 128 PM EST Thu Jan 21 2016: 321 AM EST Thu Jan 21 2016 |date=January 21, 2016 |publisher=Weather Prediction Center |accessdate=January 21, 2016 |url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/discussions/hpcdiscussions.php?disc%3Dqpfpfd%26version%3D2%26fmt%3Dreg |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/6eiKnpAOi?url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/discussions/hpcdiscussions.php?disc=qpfpfd&version=2&fmt=reg |dead-url=yes |archive-date=January 22, 2016 |df= }} The incipient storm system began to intensify as it tracked eastward through the [[Gulf Coast]] states, triggering a line of strong to severe thunderstorms and multiple tornado warnings.{{cite web|author=Steve Goss|title=Day 1 Convective Outlook: 0150 PM CST Thu Jan 21 2016|publisher=Storm Prediction Center|accessdate=Jan 21, 2016|url=http://www.spc.noaa.gov/products/outlook/archive/2016/day1otlk_20160121_2000.html}} During the mid-afternoon hours of January 22, a new low-pressure area began to develop over the coast of the [[Carolinas]] as the former storm tracked into central [[Georgia (U. S. state)|Georgia]]. Owing to uncertainty in short-range guidance but a high confidence of a sharp northern edge of precipitation, many forecasts until just hours before snowfall began were predicting 12" of snow or less from Allentown, Pennsylvania, toward New York City and the southern coast of New England. As the storm moved further north and rapidly strengthened, it became apparent that snowfall would be much higher farther north and forecasters quickly began upgrading their totals.{{cite web|last1=Burke|first1=Patrick|last2=Orisson|first2=Andrew|title=Storm Summary Number 04 For Eastern U.S. Major Winter Storm|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/winter_storm_summaries/storm1/stormsum_4.html|website=Weather Prediction Center|publisher=National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|accessdate=January 22, 2016|location=College Park, Maryland|date=January 22, 2016}} Early on January 24, as the storm was leaving New England, the system began to become elongated, as a secondary low developed to the southwest of the storm's central low.[http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/archives/web_pages/sfc/sfc_archive_maps.php?arcdate=01/24/2016&selmap=2016012409&maptype=satsfcnps WPC surface analysis valid for 01/24/2016 at 09 UTC] On January 25, the blizzard left the East Coast of the United States; on the same day, the system was named ''Karin'' by the University of Berlin.http://www.met.fu-berlin.de/de/wetter/maps/Analyse_20160125.gif Accompanied by a strong jet stream in the Atlantic, the remnants of the storm crossed the [[British Isles]] on January 26. The wind and rain associated with the low was forecast to have the potential to cause disruption in the United Kingdom,{{cite news|date=January 25, 2016|title=Rain and strong winds this week|url=http://www.metoffice.gov.uk/news/releases/archive/2016/rain-and-strong-winds|publisher=The Met Office|accessdate=January 26, 2016}} and indeed there were areas that saw severe weather.{{cite news|date=January 27, 2016|title=Worst Storm for a Century|url=http://www.express.co.uk/news/weather/637723/Weather-latest-UK-forecast-worst-storm-in-century-red-alert-Tuesday|publisher=Express|accessdate=January 29, 2016}} During the next few days, the system accelerated towards the northeast. On January 29, the storm system was absorbed by Windstorm Leone, over [[Finland]].http://www.met.fu-berlin.de/de/wetter/maps/Analyse_20160129.gif ==Preparations== Multiple offices of the [[National Weather Service]] issued various watches and warnings across the storm's projected path. [[Blizzard warning]]s covered coastal [[Connecticut]]; most of [[Delaware]]; most of [[Maryland]]; [[Massachusetts]], particularly [[Martha's Vineyard]]; most of [[New Jersey]]; [[New York (state)|New York]], including [[New York City]]; [[Pennsylvania]]; [[Rhode Island]], especially [[Block Island]]; [[Virginia]]; and Washington, D.C.{{cite web|work=Various [[National Weather Service]] offices |publisher=[[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration]] |date=January 22, 2016 |accessdate=January 22, 2016 |title=Blizzard Warnings Across the United States on January 22, 2016 |url=http://forecast.weather.gov/wwamap/wwatxtget.php?cwa=usa&wwa=Blizzard%20Warning |archivedate=January 23, 2016 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6ek6aYBkl?url=http://forecast.weather.gov/wwamap/wwatxtget.php?cwa=usa&wwa=Blizzard%20Warning |deadurl=yes |df= }} [[Winter storm warning]]s were issued from [[Arkansas]] to Massachusetts, including parts of [[Connecticut]], northern [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], extreme southern [[Illinois]], extreme southern [[Indiana]], the entirety of [[Kentucky]], extreme northeastern [[Louisiana]], southeastern Massachusetts, northeastern [[Mississippi]], extreme southeastern [[Missouri]], extreme southern New York, most of [[North Carolina]], southern [[Ohio]], southern [[Rhode Island]], northern [[South Carolina]], most of [[Tennessee]], most of [[Virginia]], and all of [[West Virginia]].{{cite web|work=Various [[National Weather Service]] offices |publisher=[[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration]] |date=January 21, 2016 |accessdate=January 21, 2016 |title=Winter Storm Warnings Across the United States on January 21, 2016 |url=http://forecast.weather.gov/wwamap/wwatxtget.php?cwa=usa&wwa=Winter%20Storm%20Warning |archivedate=January 21, 2016 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6ei8vTSL7?url=http://forecast.weather.gov/wwamap/wwatxtget.php?cwa=usa&wwa=Winter%20Storm%20Warning |deadurl=yes |df= }}{{cite web|work=Various [[National Weather Service]] offices |publisher=[[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration]] |date=January 22, 2016 |accessdate=January 22, 2016 |title=Winter Storm Warnings Across the United States on January 22, 2016 |url=http://forecast.weather.gov/wwamap/wwatxtget.php?cwa=usa&wwa=Winter%20Storm%20Warning |archivedate=January 22, 2016 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6ejdGZoQo?url=http://forecast.weather.gov/wwamap/wwatxtget.php?cwa=usa&wwa=Winter%20Storm%20Warning |deadurl=yes |df= }} [[freezing rain advisory|Freezing rain advisories]] covered parts of North and South Carolina.{{cite web|work=Various [[National Weather Service]] offices |publisher=[[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration]] |date=January 21, 2016 |accessdate=January 21, 2016 |title=Winter Storm Warnings Across the United States on January 21, 2016 |url=http://forecast.weather.gov/wwamap/wwatxtget.php?cwa=usa&wwa=Freezing%20Rain%20Advisory |archivedate=January 21, 2016 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6ei5hrkR4?url=http://forecast.weather.gov/wwamap/wwatxtget.php?cwa=usa&wwa=Freezing%20Rain%20Advisory |deadurl=yes |df= }} Further winter weather advisories covered additional portions of the country, including eastern [[Kansas]], southeastern Missouri, and northern [[Alabama]].{{cite web|work=Various [[National Weather Service]] offices |publisher=[[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration]] |date=January 21, 2016 |accessdate=January 21, 2016 |title=Winter Weather Advisories Across the United States on January 21, 2016 |url=http://forecast.weather.gov/wwamap/wwatxtget.php?cwa=usa&wwa=Winter%20Weather%20Advisory |archivedate=January 21, 2016 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6ei8Q5dN6?url=http://forecast.weather.gov/wwamap/wwatxtget.php?cwa=usa&wwa=Winter%20Weather%20Advisory |deadurl=yes |df= }} Offshore, [[storm warning]]s covered areas from Georgia to [[Maine]].{{cite web|work=Various [[National Weather Service]] offices |publisher=[[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration]] |date=January 21, 2016 |accessdate=January 21, 2016 |title=Storm Warnings Across the United States on January 21, 2016 |url=http://forecast.weather.gov/wwamap/wwatxtget.php?cwa=usa&wwa=Storm%20Warning |archivedate=January 21, 2016 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6ei66TZm2?url=http://forecast.weather.gov/wwamap/wwatxtget.php?cwa=usa&wwa=Storm%20Warning |deadurl=yes |df= }}{{cite web|work=Various [[National Weather Service]] offices |publisher=[[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration]] |date=January 22, 2016 |accessdate=January 22, 2016 |title=Storm Warnings Across the United States on January 22, 2016 |url=http://forecast.weather.gov/wwamap/wwatxtget.php?cwa=usa&wwa=Storm%20Warning |archivedate=January 22, 2016 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6ejdRajzS?url=http://forecast.weather.gov/wwamap/wwatxtget.php?cwa=usa&wwa=Storm%20Warning |deadurl=yes |df= }} On January 21–22, the governors of Delaware,{{cite news|work=[[WTXF-TV]]|publisher=[[21st Century Fox]]|date=January 22, 2016|accessdate=January 22, 2016|title=State of Emergency Issued for Delaware, Level 1 Driving Warning Starts at Midnight|url=http://www.fox29.com/news/79941774-story|location=Wilmington, Delaware}} Georgia,{{cite news|work=[[WXIA-TV]]|publisher=[[NBCUniversal]]|date=January 21, 2016|accessdate=January 21, 2016|title=State of emergency list in Georgia extended to 21 counties|url=http://www.11alive.com/story/weather/2016/01/21/two-new-counties-added-georgia-state-emergency/79125410/|location=Atlanta, Georgia}}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Kentucky,{{cite news|author=Greg Kocher|newspaper=[[Lexington Herald-Leader]]|date=January 22, 2016|accessdate=January 22, 2016|title= Bevin declares emergency as snow buries much of Kentucky|url=http://www.kentucky.com/news/local/counties/fayette-county/article56019145.html|location=Lexington, Kentucky}} Maryland, New York,{{cite web|publisher=[[Government of New York (state)|Government of New York]]|date=January 23, 2016|accessdate=January 23, 2016|title=Governor Cuomo Declares State of Emergency for New York City, Long Island, and Lower Hudson Valley as Winter Storm Hits Region|url=https://www.governor.ny.gov/news/governor-cuomo-declares-state-emergency-new-york-city-long-island-and-lower-hudson-valley}} New Jersey,{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|newspaper=[[Bristol Herald Courier]]|date=January 22, 2016|accessdate=January 22, 2016|title=New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie declares state of emergency ahead of blizzard, flooding|url=http://www.heraldcourier.com/news/new-jersey-gov-chris-christie-declares-state-of-emergency-ahead/article_9d3e1241-b810-5507-8fb3-203aab471bfc.html|location=Newark, New Jersey}}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} North Carolina,{{cite news|author1=Joe Marusak |author2=David Perlmutt |newspaper=[[The Charlotte Observer]]|date=January 21, 2016|accessdate=January 21, 2016|title=Snow, wintry mix begins to fall in Charlotte area; CMS cancels school|url=http://www.charlotteobserver.com/news/local/article55786385.html|location=Charlotte, North Carolina}} Virginia, Pennsylvania,{{cite news|work=[[WPVI-TV]]|publisher=[[The Walt Disney Company]]|date=January 21, 2016|accessdate=January 21, 2016|title=Gov. Wolf Declares State of Emergency for Pennsylvania Ahead of Snowstorm|url=http://6abc.com/weather/gov-wolf-declares-state-of-emergency-for-pennsylvania-/1168270/|location=Harrisburg, Pennsylvania}} Tennessee,{{cite news|newspaper=[[Chattanooga Times Free Press]]|date=January 21, 2016|accessdate=January 21, 2016|title=Tennessee declares state of emergency ahead of 'blizzard-like conditions'|url=http://www.timesfreepress.com/news/local/story/2016/jan/21/state-emergency-declared-tennessee/345914/|location=Chattanooga, Tennessee}} West Virginia,{{cite news|work=[[WSAZ-TV]]|publisher=[[NBCUniversal]]|date=January 22, 2016|accessdate=January 22, 2016|title=W.Va. Governor issues State of Emergency|location=Charleston, West Virginia|url=http://www.wsaz.com/content/news/WVa-Governor-issues-State-of-Emergency-366192161.html}} and the mayor of Washington, D.C. declared a [[state of emergency]] in anticipation of significant snowfall and blizzard conditions. Airlines cancelled more than 1,000 flights, with hundreds more preemptively grounded, by the afternoon of January 21 for January 22–24. Ripple effect cancellations spread across the entire East Coast.{{cite news|author1=Ben Mutzabaugh |author2=Harriet Baskas |newspaper=[[USA Today]]|date=January 21, 2016|accessdate=January 21, 2016|title=East Coast blizzard already a travel nightmare|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/travel/flights/todayinthesky/2016/01/21/snow-storm-flight-cancellations/79119110/}} By the afternoon of January 23, more than 10,100 flights were cancelled across the country, affecting well over 100,000 travelers.{{cite news|author=Carla Caldwell|newspaper=Atlanta Business Chronicle|date=January 22, 2016|accessdate=January 22, 2016|title=Close to 5,000 flights cancelled due to storm; Delta drops fee to reschedule (Update)|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/atlanta/morning_call/2016/01/delta-issues-winter-weather-advisory-fee-dropped.html}} Nearly 2,000 more flights were delayed.{{cite news|author=Samantha Masunaga|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=January 22, 2016|accessdate=January 22, 2016|title=Thousands of flights canceled or delayed as East Coast snowstorm brews|url=http://www.latimes.com/business/la-fi-canceled-flights-20160122-story.html|location=Los Angeles, California}} Most airports in the Mid-Atlantic region suspended service altogether, with [[Baltimore–Washington International Airport|Baltimore–Washington International]], [[Philadelphia International Airport]], [[Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport|Ronald Reagan Washington National]], and [[Washington Dulles International Airport|Washington Dulles International]] closed through the evening of January 24.{{cite web|author1=Greg Botelho |author2=Ralph Ellis |author3=Phil Gast |publisher=[[CNN]]|date=January 22, 2016|accessdate=January 22, 2016|title=Blizzard with 'life and death implications' hits D.C., Mid-Atlantic|url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/01/22/us/winter-snowstorm-washington-blizzard/}} Flights to and from [[LaGuardia Airport|LaGuardia]], [[John F. Kennedy International Airport|John F. Kennedy International]], and [[Newark Liberty International Airport|Newark Liberty International]] were largely cancelled as well. American Airlines suspended all flights departing from [[Charlotte-Douglas International Airport]] in North Carolina, causing a ripple of flights being cancelled throughout the country. Effects rippled internationally, with more than 100 flights in [[Canada]], [[Mexico]], and the [[United Kingdom]] cancelled.{{cite news|author=Ben Mutzabaugh|newspaper=[[USA Today]]|date=January 23, 2016|accessdate=January 23, 2016|title=Blizzard 2016: 10,000 flight cancellations and counting|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/travel/flights/todayinthesky/2016/01/23/blizzard-2016-air-travel-nightmare-extends-into-saturday/79220674/|location=Washington, D.C.}}{{cite news|publisher=[[CBC News]]|date=January 23, 2016|accessdate=January 23, 2016|title=U.S. storm delays, cancels Saturday flights at Pearson|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/toronto/us-storm-flight-delays-1.3416885}}{{cite news|newspaper=[[Irish Examiner]]|date=January 23, 2016|accessdate=January 23, 2016|title=UK cancels dozens of flights after blizzard batters America's east coast|url=http://www.irishexaminer.com/examviral/science-world/uk-cancels-dozens-of-flights-after-blizzard-batters-americas-east-coast-377879.html}} Altogether, 13,046 flights were cancelled between January 22 and 26.
