[[Amtrak]] suspended service for many lines, including the {{Amtrak trains|Crescent}} service from New York City to [[New Orleans]]; the {{Amtrak trains|Cardinal}} to [[Chicago]]; and the {{Amtrak trains|Silver Meteor}} to [[Miami]].{{cite news|author1=Alex Johnson |author2=Jon Schuppe |publisher=[[NBC News]]|date=January 22, 2016|accessdate=January 22, 2016|title=Blizzard 2016: Millions in the Path of Monster Snowstorm |url=http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/monster-storm/blizzard-2016-millions-path-monster-snowstorm-n501601}} Multiple sporting events, including those held by the [[Atlantic Coast Conference]], [[National Basketball Association]], and the [[National Hockey League]], were postponed by the storm, while the [[National Football League|National Football League's]] [[Arizona Cardinals]] vs. [[Carolina Panthers]] NFC Championship went on as planned for January 24 in [[Charlotte, North Carolina]].{{cite news|url=https://www.dailystar.com.lb/Sports/Basketball/2016/Jan-22/333503-us-blizzard-forces-nba-nhl-postponements.ashx|title=US blizzard forces NBA, NHL postponements|publisher=[[The Daily Star (Lebanon)|The Daily Star]]|location=[[Beirut]]|date=January 22, 2016|accessdate=January 22, 2016}}{{cite news|url=http://www.cbssports.com/collegebasketball/eye-on-college-basketball/25457446/winter-storm-jonas-forces-virginia-to-move-syracuse-wake-forest-games|title=Winter Storm Jonas forces postponements across college basketball|publisher=[[CBS Sports]]|date=January 22, 2016|accessdate=January 22, 2016}} ===Mid-Atlantic=== [[File:Noaa-forecast-20160122.gif|thumb|right|250px|Forecast of expected weather conditions across the eastern United States for Saturday, January 23. Blue indicates snow, green indicates rain, and purple indicates mixed precipitation. Darker shades denote heavier precipitation.]] A [[snow emergency]] was declared for Washington, D.C., meaning that residents would not be allowed to park on snow emergency routes after 9:30 p.m. local time on January 22. Mayor Bowser urged people to remain home during the storm, "[u]nless you absolutely have to be out tomorrow afternoon [January 22], residents should get home as soon as possible".{{cite news|work=[[WJLA-TV]]|publisher=[[Sinclair Broadcast Group]]|date=January 21, 2016|accessdate=January 21, 2016|title=State of emergency declared in D.C., schools closed Friday|url=http://wjla.com/news/local/state-of-emergency-declared-in-dc-schools-closed-friday|location=Washington, D.C.}} Across Maryland, 2,700 pieces of snow equipment were mobilized and crews planned to distribute 365,000 tons of road salt. In Virginia, 500 vehicles were deployed to treat roads and 500 members of the [[Virginia National Guard]] were placed on standby.{{cite news|work=[[WTOP-FM]]|publisher=[[Hubbard Broadcasting]]|date=January 21, 2016|accessdate=January 21, 2016|title=Md., Va., D.C. declare states of emergency|url=http://wtop.com/winter/2016/01/va-governor-declares-state-of-emergency-ahead-of-winter-storm/|location=Washington, D.C.}} Schools across the [[Washington, D.C. Metropolitan Area|D.C. area]] were scheduled to end classes early on January 22, before the storm's arrival.{{cite news|work=[[WRC-TV]]|publisher=[[NBCUniversal]]|date=January 21, 2016|accessdate=January 21, 2016|title=Area Schools Cancel, Delay Classes Due to Snow|url=http://www.nbcwashington.com/news/local/Area-Schools-Mulling-Closures-Delays-Due-to-Snow-365992121.html}} Stores across Maryland, Virginia, and Washington, D.C. reported a substantial uptick in sales, with groceries, heaters, shovels, and similar items sold out in numerous locations.{{cite news|author=Greg Botelho and Ed Payne|publisher=[[CNN]]|date=January 21, 2016|accessdate=January 21, 2016|title=Snowstorm threatens East; Washington, Baltimore under blizzard warnings|url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/01/21/us/winter-snowstorm-washington-blizzard/}} West Virginia Governor [[Earl Ray Tomblin]] mobilized the [[West Virginia National Guard|state's National Guard]] on January 21.{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|publisher=[[Fox News]]|date=January 21, 2016|accessdate=January 21, 2016|title=States of emergency declared as East Coast braces for winter storm|url=http://www.foxnews.com/us/2016/01/21/light-snow-causes-dc-traffic-nightmare-ahead-paralyzing-winter-storm.html}} [[File:2016-01-22 10 06 42 Variable message signs reading 'Blizzard Warning - Fri-Sat' on the southbound outer loop of the Capital Beltway (Interstate 495) in McLean, Fairfax County, Virginia-cropped.jpg|thumb|left|[[Variable-message sign|Variable-message highway signs]] in Maryland and Virginia displayed warnings of the impending blizzard]] The [[Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority]] (WMATA) announced on January 21 that it would shut down its entire [[mass transit]] system over the weekend of January 22 and 23, including the [[Washington Metro]] and [[Metrobus (Washington, D.C.)|Metrobus]], making it the longest such shutdown in the agency's history.{{cite news |last1=Halsey III |first1=Ashley |last2=Duggan |first2=Paul |date=January 21, 2016 |title=D.C. region braces for epic blizzard; Metro to shut down subway, bus lines |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/dc-region-braces-for-snowstorm-as-it-continues-to-struggle-with-one-inch-from-last-night/2016/01/21/8744619e-c041-11e5-83d4-42e3bceea902_story.html |newspaper=The Washington Post |accessdate=January 22, 2016}}{{cite press release |date=January 21, 2016 |title=Metro to suspend service during blizzard |url=http://www.wmata.com/about_metro/news/PressReleaseDetail.cfm?ReleaseID=6029 |publisher=[[Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority]] |accessdate=January 22, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160123194140/http://www.wmata.com/about_metro/news/PressReleaseDetail.cfm?ReleaseID=6029# |archive-date=2016-01-23 |dead-url=yes |df= }} On January 25, the WMATA operated limited Metro bus service, as well as rail service only on the underground portions of the [[Red Line (Washington Metro)|Red]], [[Green Line (Washington Metro)|Green]], and [[Orange Line (Washington Metro)|Orange]] Lines; however, fares were not charged.{{cite web|title = Metro plans restoration of limited underground Metrorail, "lifeline" Metrobus service for Monday, January 25|url = http://wmata.com/about_metro/news/PressReleaseDetail.cfm?ReleaseID=6031|date = January 24, 2016|accessdate = January 24, 2016|publisher = Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority (WMATA)|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20160127021644/http://www.wmata.com/about_metro/news/PressReleaseDetail.cfm?ReleaseID=6031#|archive-date = 2016-01-27|dead-url = yes|df = }} In [[Richmond, Virginia]], all flights out of [[Richmond International Airport]] on January 23 were cancelled,{{cite news|last1=Hylton|first1=David|last2=Bahorich|first2=Susan|title=Flights, bus travel canceled out of Richmond|url=http://www.nbc12.com/story/31038058/all-morning-flights-canceled-at-ric|accessdate=27 January 2016|work=NBC 12 News|agency=WWBT|date=23 January 2016}} and the [[Greater Richmond Transit Company]] (GTRC) bus system took the rare step of suspending all routes on January 24.{{cite news|last1=Oliver|first1=Ned|title=11th biggest snowfall on record for Richmond; schools cancel classes|url=http://www.richmond.com/weather/article_9b0aaef4-5229-549b-a7a3-681c669e7d5f.html|accessdate=27 January 2016|work=Richmond Times-Dispatch|date=24 January 2016}} [[File:Massive Snowdrifts from the Blizzard.jpg|thumb|Five-foot snow drifts in Reading, Pennsylvania]] The [[Pennsylvania Department of Transportation]] had 2,200 vehicles and more than 733,000 tons of road salt on standby for use. Trucks deployed [[brine]] across major roads in and around [[Philadelphia]], though residents were advised to avoid travel unless necessary. A travel ban was declared for Lancaster, [[Lebanon, Pennsylvania|Lebanon]], [[Newberry Township, York County, Pennsylvania|Newberry Township]], and [[York, Pennsylvania|York]] on January 23.{{cite news|work=[[WGAL]]|publisher=[[Hearst Corporation]]|date=January 23, 2016|accessdate=January 23, 2016|title=Lebanon declares state of emergency, travel ban|url=http://www.wgal.com/news/state-of-disaster-travel-ban-declared-in-lebanon/37597310|location=Lebanon, Pennsylvania}}{{cite news|author=Megan Trimble|work=PA Media Group|publisher=[[Advance Digital]]|date=January 23, 2016|accessdate=January 23, 2016|title=Disaster Emergency: Travel bans issued in York County|url=http://www.pennlive.com/news/2016/01/disaster_emergency_travel_ban.html}} The [[Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority]] issued a near complete shutdown of its services, shutting down all bus services and closing all rail except for the [[Broad Street Line]] and [[Market-Frankford Line]] subways.{{cite news|work=[[philly.com]]|publisher=[[Philadelphia Media Network]], LLC|date=January 23, 2016|accessdate=January 23, 2016|title=Transportation agencies brace for storm|url=http://www.philly.com/philly/business/transportation/20160123_Transportation_agencies_brace_for_storm.html|location=Philadelphia, Pennsylvania}} [[File:Ladder 4 backing in Jan 2016 snow jeh.jpg|thumb|left|Emergency services in New York City, such as the [[New York City Fire Department|fire department]] (''pictured''), functioned during the snowstorm]] New York City mayor [[Bill de Blasio]] declared a hazardous travel advisory for the city, encouraging people not to travel; however, he did not ban traveling.{{cite news|work=[[WABC-TV]]|publisher=[[The Walt Disney Company]]|date=January 21, 2016|accessdate=January 21, 2016|title=New York City Prepared for Winter Storm De Blasio Says|url=http://abc7ny.com/weather/de-blasio-issues-travel-advisory-before-weekend-winter-storm/1168066/|location=New York, New York}} On January 22, he declared a "winter weather emergency" and told residents to "Get done what you have to get done today ... Do not bring your vehicle out tomorrow". Taking place a year after a storm prompted the closure of the [[New York City Subway|city's subway system]] in [[January 2015 North American blizzard|January 2015]], only to largely bypass the city, Governor [[Andrew Cuomo]] stated that services would remain running. Approximately 1,800 workers equipped with 800 heaters were to keep rails clear for use. Thousands of sanitation workers, 1,700 plows, and 150,000 tons of road salt were on standby to clear city roads. He also put 600 members of the [[New York National Guard]] on standby. More than 50 power workers from Vermont were dispatched to Long Island to help restore power outages.{{cite web|author=Dorothy Schnure|date=January 22, 2016|accessdate=January 26, 2016|title=GMP Sends Crews South to Help with Massive Snowstorn|website=vtdigger.com|url=https://vtdigger.org/2016/01/22/gmp-sends-crews-south-to-help-with-massive-snowstorm/|location=Colchester, Vermont}} Around noon on January 23, owing to a significant increase in expected snowfall, Cuomo issued a travel ban for all roads in New York City and [[Long Island]]. The [[New York City Transit Authority]] suspended [[MTA Regional Bus Operations|bus]] service; rail service on the [[Long Island Rail Road]], [[Metro-North Railroad|Metro-North]], and [[Staten Island Railway]]; and elevated subway service (with underground subway lines remaining open until further notice). In the meantime, the [[Port Authority of New York and New Jersey]] closed bridges and tunnels in the region.{{cite news|work=[[WNYW]]|publisher=[[21st Century Fox]]|date=January 23, 2016|accessdate=January 23, 2016|title=Travel ban in New York City|url=http://www.fox5ny.com/news/81021383-story}} A travel ban was instituted for [[Newark, New Jersey]], on January 23 through the afternoon of January 24 in light of hundreds of snow-related accidents.{{cite web|author= Myles Ma|work=New Jersey On-Line|publisher=[[Advance Digital]]|date=January 24, 2016|accessdate=January 25, 2016|title=Newark mayor extends travel ban to 1 p.m.|url=http://www.nj.com/essex/index.ssf/2016/01/newark_mayor_extends_travel_ban_to_1_pm.html|location=Newark, New Jersey}} Strong winds coupled with prolonged onshore flow resulted in a major coastal flood threat for Delaware and New Jersey. Near-shore waves were forecast to reach {{convert|15|to|20|ft|m|abbr=on}} with a [[storm surge]] of {{convert|3|to|5|ft|m|abbr=on}}. In New Jersey, a mandatory evacuation was ordered for residents in coastal [[Barnegat Township, New Jersey|Barnegat Township]] in anticipation of significant coastal flooding; several other towns were placed under voluntary evacuation orders.{{cite news|work=[[WNBC]]|publisher=[[NBCUniversal]]|date=January 22, 2016|accessdate=January 22, 2016|title='Winter Weather Emergency' Declared in NYC Ahead of Nor'easter|url=http://www.nbcnewyork.com/news/local/NY-NJ-CT-Winter-Blizzard-Warning-Issued-as-Powerful-Snowstorm-Jonas-Approaches-Ice-Wind-Snow-366170501.html|location=New York, New York}} Delaware Governor [[Jack Markell]] declared a "level 1 driving warning", encouraging people not to travel and indicating drivers should be extra cautious. The [[Delaware Department of Transportation]] had 330 snow plows ready to clear roads, though many areas were expected to be impassible on January 23. Shelters were also opened for the homeless. In [[New Castle County, Delaware|New Castle County]] and [[Kent County, Delaware|Kent County]] in Delaware the [[Delaware Department of Transportation|Department of Transportation]] and Governor [[Jack Markell]] declared a Level 2 driving restriction (essential personnel on the roads only.){{Cite web|title = WDEL 101.7FM – 2016 Delaware Blizzard Storm Hub, Day 2 – Level 2 Driving Restrictions now in place|url = http://www.wdel.com/story/73053-2016-delaware-blizzard-storm-hub-day-2-level-2-driving-restrictions-now-in-place|website = www.wdel.com|access-date = 2016-01-28|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20160127074436/http://wdel.com/story/73053-2016-delaware-blizzard-storm-hub-day-2-level-2-driving-restrictions-now-in-place#|archive-date = 2016-01-27|dead-url = yes|df = }} ===Southeast=== Anticipating a damaging ice storm, approximately 4,500 linemen were placed on standby to repair downed power lines in North Carolina; 1,000 state transportation workers also prepared for heavy snowfall, with crews placed on 12-hour shifts to be deployed as needed. Crews from across the country arrived to assist North Carolina power companies. Two million gallons of brine were used to pre-treat roads statewide. Across Tennessee, state offices closed for January 22, warming centers opened, and the [[Red Cross]] placed shelters on standby.{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|publisher=[[Chattanooga Times Free Press]]|date=January 22, 2016|accessdate=January 22, 2016|title=Snow, freezing rain fall across much of Tennessee|url=http://www.timesfreepress.com/news/national/tennessee/story/2016/jan/22/snow-freezing-rafall-across-much-tennessee/346103/|location=Nashville, Tennessee}} The [[Tennessee Highway Patrol]] asked for people to remain off the roads, saying, "We are desperately asking you please DON'T DRIVE".{{cite tweet|user=TNHighwayPatrol|author=Tennessee Highway Patrol|date=January 22, 2016|accessdate=January 22, 2016|title=If you are thinking about going out for a Friday night on the town DON'T! We are desperately asking you please DON'T DRIVE. #STAYN|number=690628680444436480}} ===British Isles=== The storm was forecast to cross the Atlantic Ocean and affect the [[British Isles]] from January 26 to 28. The storm was expected to be less severe, with rain rather than snow; however, the possibility of strong winds and localized flooding was noted.{{cite news|author=Alexandra Sims|newspaper=[[The Independent]]|date=January 23, 2016|accessdate=January 26, 2016|title=UK weather: Storm Jonas on way to Britain as low pressure system moves across Atlantic|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/extras/weather/uk-weather-storm-jonas-to-come-to-britain-as-low-pressure-system-heads-across-atlantic-a6829881.html}} Particular concern was raised over areas that [[2015–16 Great Britain and Ireland floods|suffered from significant flooding]] during the preceding months.{{cite news|publisher=[[Sky News]]|date=January 25, 2016|accessdate=January 26, 2016|title=UK on alert as snowstorm crosses Atlantic|url=http://www.skynews.com.au/news/world/europe/2016/01/25/uk-on-alert-as-snowstorm-crosses-atlantic.html}}{{cite news|publisher=[[BBC]]|date=January 25, 2016|accessdate=January 26, 2016|title=US snow storm to bring heavy rain and gales to UK|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-35398040|location=London, United Kingdom}} Wind gusts as high as {{convert|70|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} were forecast for the [[Hebrides]] and {{convert|50|to|60|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} for coastal [[Scotland]].{{cite news|newspaper=[[Belfast Telegraph]]|date=January 26, 2016|accessdate=January 26, 2016|title=Weather alert as Northern Ireland faces heavy downpours|url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/northern-ireland/weather-alert-as-northern-ireland-faces-heavy-downpours-34394059.html|location=Belfast, Northern Ireland}} The storm in the British Isles was far less severe than in the United States and [[Storm Gertrude]] a few days later may have been worse.[[BBC]](London) 29/01/2016 [https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-35436955 Storm Gertrude: Gales cause chaos across parts of UK] ==Impact== {{Multiple image |direction=vertical |align=right |width=250 |image1=January 2016 United States blizzard aftermath.jpg |caption1=View of the eastern United States at 1:30 p.m. EST (18:30 UTC) on January 24 after the blizzard subsided. Snow blankets the region, highlighting local topographic and hydrologic features. |image2=January 2016 United States blizzard RSI map.png |caption2=[[Regional Snowfall Index]] analysis of the storm }} The storm's widespread effects paralyzed travel across the eastern United States as it produced more than {{convert|20|in|cm|abbr=on}} of snow across a large area along the [[Appalachian Mountains]].{{cite news|author1=Barbara Goldberg |author2=Idrees Ali |publisher=[[Reuters]] |date=January 23, 2016 |accessdate=January 23, 2016 |title=Blizzard intensifies as it slams New York, floods New Jersey |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-weather-idUSKCN0V107L |archivedate=January 23, 2016 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6el5PWqNc?url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-weather-idUSKCN0V107L |location=New York, New York |deadurl=yes |df= }} At least 55 fatalities have been attributed to the storm and its aftermath: 12 in Virginia, 9 in Pennsylvania, 6 in New Jersey, 6 in New York, 6 in North Carolina, 4 in South Carolina, 3 in Maryland, 3 in Washington, D.C., 1 in Arkansas, 1 in Delaware, 1 in Georgia, 1 in Kentucky, 1 in Massachusetts, and 1 in Ohio.{{cite news|author=Frank Lewis|newspaper=[[Portsmouth Daily Times]]|date=January 23, 2016|accessdate=January 23, 2016|title=Sledding teen killed by truck|url=http://portsmouth-dailytimes.com/news/5247/sledding-teen-killed-by-truck}} Throughout the affected region, more than 631,000 people lost power: 270,000 in New Jersey,{{cite web|agency=National Weather Service Office in Mt. Holly, New Jersey|publisher=National Centers for Environmental Information|year=2016|accessdate=April 20, 2016|title=New Jersey Event Report|url=http://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/stormevents/eventdetails.jsp?id=614491}} 147,000 in North Carolina, 66,000 in Georgia, 55,000 in Virginia, 47,000 collectively in Delaware and Maryland,{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|work=[[WTOP-FM]]|publisher=[[Hubbard Broadcasting]]|date=January 24, 2016|accessdate=January 26, 2016|title=Power restored across much of the Mid-Atlantic region|url=http://wtop.com/local/2016/01/power-restored-across-much-of-the-mid-atlantic-region/|location=Baltimore, Maryland|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160128120357/http://wtop.com/local/2016/01/power-restored-across-much-of-the-mid-atlantic-region/#|archive-date=2016-01-28|dead-url=yes|df=}} and nearly 30,000 in South Carolina. Economic losses—from lost sales revenue and wages—are estimated between $500 million and $3 billion. [[Moody's Analytics]] indicated the highest losses, stating $2.5–3 billion; however, the storm's occurrence on a weekend accounted for less losses than what would otherwise be expected.{{cite news|agency=[[CNN]]|work=[[WTVR-TV]]|publisher=[[Tribune Media]]|date=January 25, 2016|accessdate=January 25, 2016|title=Blizzard will cost up to $3 billion|url=http://wtvr.com/2016/01/25/blizzard-will-cost-up-to-3-billion/|location=New York, New York}} [[Planalytics]] placed losses at $850 million and [[Global Insight|IHS Global Insight]] estimated losses between $500 million and $1 billion. Although an estimate was not provided, [[Aon (company)|AON Benfield]] placed losses in the billions of dollars, noting similarities to the [[North American blizzard of 1996|Blizzard of 1996]] which inflicted $4.6 billion in economic losses.{{cite news|author=Jonathan Berr|publisher=[[CBS News]]|date=January 25, 2016|accessdate=January 26, 2016|title=This blizzard may land a $3 billion blow|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/this-blizzard-may-land-a-3-billion-blow/}} Despite the expected major losses, the rush to buy supplies ahead of the storm's arrival may mitigate the overall impact.{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|publisher=[[CBS News]]|date=January 25, 2016|accessdate=January 26, 2016|title=Blizzard's hit on economy in hundreds of millions?|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/winter-storm-2016-blizzards-hit-on-economy-in-hundreds-of-millions/|location=Washington, D.C.}} The airline industry suffered approximately $200 million in lost revenue.{{cite news|author=Benjamin Zhang|publisher=[[Business Insider]]|date=January 25, 2016|accessdate=January 25, 2016|title=Airlines could lose $200 million due to the blizzard – but they won't feel the pain|url=http://www.businessinsider.com.au/blizzard-costs-airlines-hundreds-of-millions-in-revenue-2016-1}} Using the [[Regional Snowfall Index]], the storm ranked as a Category 5, "extreme", storm for the Northeast and a Category 4, "crippling", for the Southeast. It was also ranked as a Category 3, "major", event in the [[Ohio Valley]]. Approximately 103 million people were in the storm's path,{{cite web|publisher=[[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration]]|date=February 18, 2016|accessdate=February 21, 2016|title=Putting the January 22–24 Snowstorm in Historical Context|url=https://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/news/january-22-24-2016-snowstorm-in-historical-context}} including 33 million in the expected blizzard area. About 21 million people in the Northeast experienced more than {{convert|20|in|cm|abbr=on}} of snow. Half of the affected people were in the Northeast (which includes the [[Northeast megalopolis]]); the storm's RSI reached 20.138 in this region, the fourth-highest on record for the region. The primary factor driving its high classification was the affected population. The storm's RSI of 13.776 in the Southeast was the twelfth-highest on record. ===Severe weather on the Gulf Coast=== {{see also|List of United States tornadoes in January 2016#January 21 event}} During January 21 through the early hours of January 22, [[severe thunderstorm]]s brought damaging winds and hail to portions of Louisiana, Mississippi, Alabama, and Florida. Five [[tornado]]es touched down across Mississippi: an [[Enhanced Fujita Scale|EF0]] near [[Crystal Springs, Mississippi|Crystal Springs]], an EF0 near [[Homewood, Mississippi|Homewood]], an EF1 near [[Loyd Star, Mississippi|Loyd Star]], an EF1 near [[Pinola, Mississippi|Pinola]], and an EF2 near [[Sumrall, Mississippi|Sumrall]]. Numerous trees and power lines were downed, multiple structures were damaged, and a few were destroyed by the tornadoes.{{cite report|work=National Weather Service Office in Jackson, Mississippi |publisher=[[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration]] |date=January 25, 2016 |accessdate=January 26, 2016 |title=NWS Damage Survey for 01/21/16 Tornado Event |url=http://forecast.weather.gov/product.php?site=JAN&product=PNS&issuedby=JAN |archivedate=January 26, 2016 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6epiNVd6P?url=http://www.nws.noaa.gov/view/validProds.php?prod=PNS&node=KJAN |deadurl=yes |df= }} Straight line winds near Improve, [[Lamar County, Mississippi]], significantly damaged 10–12 homes. Hail reached {{convert|2.75|in|cm|abbr=on}} in diameter in [[Wilmer, Louisiana]]. The most significant damage occurred overnight across the [[Florida Panhandle]] and neighboring Alabama. Winds gusting to {{convert|73|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} downed numerous trees and power lines and damaged structures.{{cite web|work=[[Storm Prediction Center]]|publisher=[[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration]]|date=January 22, 2016|accessdate=January 22, 2016|title=160121's Storm Reports (1200 UTC − 1159 UTC)|url=http://www.spc.noaa.gov/climo/reports/160121_rpts.html|location=Norman, Oklahoma}} ===Southeastern states=== [[File:Belle Meade Plantation during snowstorm on January 22, 2016.jpg|thumb|left|Snowfall at the [[Belle Meade Plantation]] in Tennessee on January 22]] Snow fell across a large portion of Arkansas on January 21–22, with a daily record of {{convert|7.2|in|cm|abbr=on}} observed just outside [[Little Rock, Arkansas|Little Rock]].{{cite report|work=National Weather Service Office in Little Rock, Arkansas |publisher=[[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration]] |date=January 22, 2016 |accessdate=January 22, 2016 |title=24-Hour Snowfall Totals for 01/21 to 01/22 |url=http://forecast.weather.gov/product.php?site=LZK&product=PNS&issuedby=LZK |archivedate=January 23, 2016 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6ejzvPpSm?url=http://forecast.weather.gov/product.php?site=LZK&product=PNS&issuedby=LZK |deadurl=yes |df= }}{{cite report|work=National Weather Service Office in Little Rock, Arkansas |publisher=[[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration]] |date=January 22, 2016 |accessdate=January 22, 2016 |title=Record Snowfall Set at North Little Rock |url=http://forecast.weather.gov/product.php?site=LZK&product=RER&issuedby=LZK |archivedate=January 23, 2016 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6ek0KCZXG?url=http://forecast.weather.gov/product.php?site=LZK&product=RER&issuedby=LZK |deadurl=yes |df= }} Snowfall was confined to the eastern half of the state, with freezing rain amounting to {{convert|0.25|in|mm|abbr=on}} observed in northeastern counties.{{cite report|work=National Weather Service Office in Little Rock, Arkansas |publisher=[[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration]] |date=January 22, 2016 |accessdate=January 22, 2016 |title=Winter Storm Summary: January 21–22, 2016 |url=http://www.srh.noaa.gov/images/lzk/pdf/win0116a.pdf |format=PDF |archivedate=January 23, 2016 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6ek01ZTzv?url=http://www.srh.noaa.gov/images/lzk/pdf/win0116a.pdf |deadurl=yes |df= }} Strong winds in excess of {{convert|35|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}—with a gust of {{convert|47|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} measured in [[Jonesboro, Arkansas|Jonesboro]]—left more than 16,000 people in the state without power. One fatality near [[Hoxie, Arkansas|Hoxie]] was due to slippery roads.{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|work=[[KTHV]]|publisher=[[Tegna, Inc.]]|date=January 22, 2016|accessdate=January 22, 2016|title=1 fatality on Arkansas highways during storm|url=http://www.thv11.com/story/news/2016/01/22/travel-treacherous-throughout-eastern-arkansas/79168620/|location=Little Rock, Arkansas|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160123213800/http://www.thv11.com/story/news/2016/01/22/travel-treacherous-throughout-eastern-arkansas/79168620/#|archive-date=2016-01-23|dead-url=yes|df=}} Early on January 22, heavy snow fell across parts of western Tennessee. Roads around [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]] quickly became impassable, including portions of Interstates [[Interstate 40 in Tennessee|40]] and [[Interstate 24 in Tennessee and Georgia|24]], and local police reported more than 200 accidents.{{cite news|author=Mark Berman|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|date=January 22, 2016|accessdate=January 22, 2016|title=Thousands of flights canceled, states of emergency declared as blizzard threatens East Coast|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-nation/wp/2016/01/22/states-of-emergency-declared-along-east-coast-thousands-of-flights-canceled-as-blizzard-approaches/|location=Washington, D.C.}} In [[Lexington, Kentucky]], one accident led to injury; 17 other accidents were reported. Multiple accidents in [[Rockcastle County, Kentucky|Rockcastle County]] prompted the closure of {{convert|12|mi|km|abbr=on}} of [[I-75 in Kentucky]]. Along a {{convert|35|mi|km|adj = on}} stretch of [[Interstate 75 in Kentucky]], hundreds of drivers became stranded for more than 16 hours on January 22–23. In a separate incident, a {{convert|11|mi|km|adj=on}} stretch of [[Interstate 77 in West Virginia]] was blocked by stuck tractor-trailers that were lying across the highway.{{cite news|author1=Greg Botelho |author2=Jason Hanna |author3=Joshua Berlinger |publisher=[[CNN]]|date=January 23, 2016|accessdate=January 23, 2016|title=Blizzard strikes East Coast; motorists stranded for hours in 3 states|url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/01/23/us/weather-winter-snowstorm/}} The National Guard was deployed to provide people with food, water, and fuel.{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|work=[[WKRN-TV]]|publisher=[[Media General]]|date=January 23, 2016|accessdate=January 23, 2016|title=Millions hunker down for snowstorm; cars stuck in Kentucky|url=http://wkrn.com/2016/01/23/tens-of-millions-hunker-down-to-ride-out-winter-storm/|location=Washington, D.C.}} A transportation worker died when his truck skidded off icy roads.{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|work=[[KTRK-TV]]|publisher=[[The Walt Disney Company]]|date=January 23, 2016|accessdate=January 23, 2016|title=Blizzard Strikes US, Blankets Millions in Snow and Ice|url=http://abc13.com/news/at-least-6-dead-as-blizzard-blankets-us-in-snow/1171201/|location=Washington, D.C.|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160124100337/http://abc13.com/news/at-least-6-dead-as-blizzard-blankets-us-in-snow/1171201/#|archive-date=2016-01-24|dead-url=yes|df=}} Treacherous road conditions in North Carolina resulted in at least 571 accidents and 800 "service calls" from police. Five deaths were reported across the state. One person died in a collision on [[Interstate 95 in North Carolina|Interstate 95]]. Numerous roads were shut down accordingly.{{cite web|author=Anna Norris|publisher=[[The Weather Channel]]|date=January 22, 2016|accessdate=January 22, 2016|title=Winter Storm Jonas Takes Fatal Turn in the South; Nashville Roads Gridlocked|url=http://www.weather.com/storms/winter/news/winter-storm-jonas-charlotte-carolinas-ga-tenn-ark|location=Atlanta, Georgia}} One person was killed and three others were injured in [[Forsyth County, North Carolina|Forsyth County]]. An accident along [[Interstate 77 in North Carolina|Interstate 77]] near [[Troutman, North Carolina|Troutman]] resulted in the death of a 4-year-old boy.{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|publisher=[[Richmond Times-Dispatch]]|date=January 22, 2016|accessdate=January 22, 2016|title=Update: At least 8 snowstorm-related deaths in Ken., Tenn., N.C.|url=http://www.richmond.com/news/national-world/ap/article_3c0f0606-c128-11e5-b76c-97e674dc5223.html|location=Richmond, Virginia}} Freezing rain resulted in widespread power outages, bringing down numerous trees and power lines in the state. Many roads closed because of debris, including portions of [[Interstate 40 in North Carolina|Interstate 40]] in [[Johnston County, North Carolina|Johnston County]]. Approximately 147,000 people lost power in North Carolina, with [[Wake County, North Carolina|Wake County]] accounting for 50,000 of the total.{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|work=[[KSNT]]|publisher=[[NBCUniversal]]|date=January 23, 2016|accessdate=January 26, 2016|title=More than 120,000 across N.C. without power|url=http://ksnt.com/2016/01/23/more-than-120000-across-n-c-without-power/|location=Raleigh, North Carolina}} Four people died in South Carolina: two from carbon monoxide poisoning in [[Greenville, South Carolina|Greenville]], one in a car accident on an icy road in [[Greenville County, South Carolina|Greenville County]], and another from an accident in [[Jonesville, South Carolina|Jonesville]].{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|work=[[WJZ-TV]]|publisher=[[CBS Corporation]]|date=January 25, 2016|accessdate=January 25, 2016|title=At Least 30 Killed In Snowstorm-Related Deaths|url=http://baltimore.cbslocal.com/2016/01/25/at-least-30-killed-in-snowstorm-related-deaths/|location=Baltimore, Maryland}} Nearly 30,000 people lost power in the state.{{cite news|newspaper=[[The State (newspaper)|The State]]|date=January 22, 2016|accessdate=January 26, 2016|title=Update: Power outages reported in the Upstate |url=http://www.thestate.com/news/local/article56032780.html|location=Columbia, South Carolina}} Portions of Interstates [[Interstate 26 in South Carolina|26]] and [[Interstate 95 in South Carolina|95]] were temporarily shut down for icy conditions.{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|work=[[WCIV]]|publisher=[[Sinclair Broadcast Group]]|date=January 23, 2016|accessdate=January 26, 2016|title=Icy conditions, power outages tail off in SC after storm|url=http://abcnews4.com/news/local/icy-conditions-power-outages-tail-off-in-sc-after-storm|location=Columbia, South Carolina}} Upwards of {{convert|8|in|cm|abbr=on}} of snow fell across Georgia, with the highest totals confined to northern parts of the state. High winds downed trees and power lines, leaving approximately 66,000 people without power across the state.{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|newspaper=[[The Augusta Chronicle]]|date=January 23, 2016|accessdate=January 23, 2016|title=Northeast Georgia receives up to 8 inches of snow|url=http://chronicle.augusta.com/latest-news/2016-01-23/northeast-georgia-receives-8-inches-snow|location=Atlanta, Georgia}} A postal worker was killed when strong winds blew a large branch off a tree, crushing him in his car.{{cite web|author=Emily Knapp|title=Snowstorm Deaths Reach 41 as East Coast Tries to Dig Out|date=January 25, 2016|publisher=ABC News|accessdate=January 25, 2016|url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/snow-clean-underway-east-coast-back-normal/story?id=36495700}} Snow fell as far south as [[Mobile, Alabama]],{{cite tweet|user=weatherchannel|author=The Weather Channel|date=January 22, 2016|accessdate=January 22, 2016|title=Snow has been reported as far south as #Mobile, Alabama. Snow showers are moving across the Florida panhandle: #flwx|number=690704845716611072}} with additional flurries extending into [[Jacksonville, Florida|Jacksonville]] and [[Gainesville, Florida|Gainesville]] along the Florida Panhandle late on January 22. Temperatures in Gainesville fell to {{convert|28|F|C|abbr=on}}.{{cite news|author=Alex Harris|newspaper=[[Miami Herald]]|date=January 23, 2016|accessdate=January 23, 2016|title= Snow in the Sunshine State: North Florida sees a few flakes|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/news/state/florida/article56236575.html|location=Miami, Florida}} ===Mid-Atlantic states=== [[File:2016 Blizzard - DC Cleveland Park.jpg|thumb|right|Aftermath of the storm in [[Cleveland Park]], Washington D.C.]] Maximum snow depth was measured at {{convert|42|in|cm|abbr=on}} in [[Glengary, West Virginia|Glengary]], [[West Virginia]], on January 24. [[Baltimore]], Maryland, recorded its largest snowfall on record.{{cite news|agency= [[The Weather Channel]]|publisher=The Weather Channel|date=January 21, 2016|accessdate=January 21, 2016|title=Winter Storm Jonas Forecast|url=http://www.weather.com/storms/winter/news/winter-storm-jonas-forecast-blizzard-warning-january-22}} Two people died from heart attacks while shoveling snow and a third from undetermined causes across Maryland.{{cite news|work=[[WJLA-TV]]|publisher=[[Sinclair Broadcast Group]]|date=January 23, 2016|accessdate=January 23, 2016|title=Man dies while shoveling snow in Maryland|url=http://wjla.com/news/local/man-dies-while-shoveling-snow-in-maryland|location=Ft. Washington, Maryland}}{{cite news|author=David Anderson|newspaper=[[The Baltimore Sun]]|date=January 23, 2016|accessdate=January 23, 2016|title= Two die in Harford during Saturday blizzard, snow expected to continue through the evening |url=http://www.baltimoresun.com/news/maryland/harford/belair/ph-ag-harford-snow-update-0127-20160123-story.html|location=Baltimore, Maryland}} A large portion of the [[Ocean City, Maryland|Ocean City]] fishing pier was destroyed by rough seas and high winds.{{cite news|author=Christine Boynton|work=[[WBFF]]|publisher=[[Sinclair Broadcast Group]]|date=January 23, 2016|accessdate=January 23, 2016|title=Ocean City fishing pier torn apart by winter storm|url=http://foxbaltimore.com/news/local/ocean-city-fishing-pier-torn-apart-by-winter-storm|location=Ocean City, Maryland}} West Virginia's emergency management reported [[Interstate 77 in West Virginia|Interstate 77]] to be "completely shut down" following an accident involving semi-trailers. The National Guard was called in to assist clearing the stranded vehicles. Six people died from snow-related incidents in Virginia.{{cite news|author=Scott Wise|work=[[WTVR-TV]]|publisher=[[Tribune Media]]|date=January 25, 2016|accessdate=January 25, 2016|title=Snowstorm blamed for 6 Virginia deaths|url=http://wtvr.com/2016/01/25/virginia-snowstorm-deaths/|location=Richmond, Virginia}} Virginia State Police responded to 989 accidents and 793 disabled vehicles through the evening of January 22. A total of 12 people died in storm-related incidents across Virginia. One person died when their car skid off a road in [[Chesapeake, Virginia|Chesapeake]] and collided with a tree. Five people died from [[hypothermia]]: one each in [[Charles City, Virginia|Charles City]], [[Gloucester County, Virginia|Gloucester County]], [[Hampton, Virginia|Hampton]], [[Henry County, Virginia|Henry County]], and [[Wise County, Virginia|Wise County]].{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|newspaper=New Jersey Herald|date=January 23, 2016|accessdate=January 23, 2016|title=At least 18 killed in snowstorm-related deaths|url=http://www.njherald.com/article/20160123/AP/301239821}} A combination of snow and ice accumulation caused the roof of [[Donk's Theatre]] in [[Hudgins, Virginia]], to collapse; the structure was deemed a total loss and will be demolished.{{cite news|author=Michael Martz|newspaper=[[Richmond Times-Dispatch]]|date=January 23, 2016|accessdate=January 23, 2016|title=Roof collapses on historic Donk's Theater, known as "Virginia's Lil Ole Opry" |location=Richmond, Virginia|url=http://www.richmond.com/weather/article_0c94ce8f-a916-597a-99fd-fa98b4a3d910.html}} The roof of a 4,700 ft2 (437 m2) building collapsed in [[Charlottesville, Virginia|Charlottesville]].{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|work=[[WTOP-FM]]|publisher=[[Hubbard Broadcasting]]|date=January 25, 2016|accessdate=January 26, 2016|title=Charlottesville roof laden with snow collapses|url=http://wtop.com/virginia/2016/01/unofficial-storm-death-toll-in-virginia-up-to-8/|location=Richmond, Virginia|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160128002428/http://wtop.com/virginia/2016/01/unofficial-storm-death-toll-in-virginia-up-to-8/#|archive-date=2016-01-28|dead-url=yes|df=}} Seven people required hospitalization for carbon monoxide poisoning at an apartment complex in [[Herndon, Virginia|Herndon]] when vents became clogged with snow.{{cite news|author=Victoria Jones|work=[[WRC-TV]]|publisher=[[NBCUniversal]]|date=January 25, 2016|accessdate=January 27, 2016|title=Blocked Vents Cause Carbon Monoxide Poisoning at Virginia Apartments|url=http://www.nbcwashington.com/news/local/Blocked-Vents-Cause-Carbon-Monoxide-Poisoning-at-Apartments-366494131.html|location=Washington, D.C.}} Three people died while shoveling snow in Washington, D.C.{{cite news|work=[[WRC-TV]]|publisher=[[NBCUniversal]]|date=January 24, 2016|accessdate=January 25, 2016|title=3 Local Deaths Attributed to Shoveling Snow|url=http://www.nbcwashington.com/news/local/Local-Deaths-Attributed-to-Blizzard-366373981.html}} [[File:Winter Storm Jonas - Fairfax Villa Neighborhood - Maple Street - 5.JPG|thumb|left| The aftermath of the blizzard in the Fairfax Villa neighborhood in [[Fairfax, Virginia]]. Unplowed streets and buried cars can be seen here.]] Snow-related incidents resulted in nine deaths across Pennsylvania. In [[Harrisburg, Pennsylvania|Harrisburg]], snowfall from the storm was reported as {{convert|30.2|in|cm|abbr=on}}, breaking the city's previous record snowfall of {{convert|25|in|cm|abbr=on}} which was set in February 1983.{{cite web|last1=Coyle|first1=Ryan|title=Largest Snowfall in Recorded History for Some Parts of Central PA|url=http://abc27.com/2016/01/20/latest-forecast-still-brings-snow-friday-night-into-saturday/|website=ABC27.com|accessdate=January 23, 2016|date=January 23, 2016}} Near [[Bedford, Pennsylvania|Bedford]], approximately 500 vehicles became stuck along a westbound stretch of the [[Pennsylvania Turnpike]] for over 24 hours from January 22–23 near the eastern approach to the [[Allegheny Mountain Tunnel]]. Among the stranded vehicles were one bus carrying the [[Duquesne University]] [[Duquesne Dukes men's basketball|men's basketball team]] and another carrying [[Temple University]]'s [[Temple Owls|women's gymnastics team]].{{cite web|title=Effort to rescue occupants of 500 vehicles stranded on Pa. Turnpike continues|url=http://www.pennlive.com/news/2016/01/effort_to_rescue_occupants_of.html|website=Pennlive.com|accessdate=January 23, 2016|date=January 23, 2016}} Despite the scale of the incident, no major injuries were reported.{{cite web|last1=Cruz|first1=Luis|title=No major injuries reported in massive traffic backup on Pa. Turnpike|url=http://abc27.com/2016/01/24/no-major-injuries-reported-in-massive-traffic-backup-on-pa-turnpike/|website=ABC27.com|accessdate=January 24, 2016|date=January 24, 2016}} The band [[Guster]], stranded in Pittsburgh by the blocking of the turnpike, held an impromptu concert in an alley.{{cite news|publisher=[[Associated Press]] |date=January 25, 2016 |accessdate=January 26, 2016 |title=Alt rock Band Guster Performs Live in Pittsburgh Alleyway |url=http://customwire.ap.org/dynamic/stories/U/US_POP_BAND_ALLEY_SHOW?SITE=AP&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT&CTIME=2016-01-25-20-31-00 |archivedate=February 6, 2016 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160206022409/http://customwire.ap.org/dynamic/stories/U/US_POP_BAND_ALLEY_SHOW?SITE=AP&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT&CTIME=2016-01-25-20-31-00 |location=Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania |deadurl=yes |df= }} Four people died while shoveling snow: two in both [[Lancaster County, Pennsylvania|Lancaster]] and [[Montgomery County, Pennsylvania|Montgomery]] counties.{{cite news|author=David Chang|work=[[WCAU]]|publisher=[[NBCUniversal]]|date=January 24, 2016|accessdate=January 25, 2016|title=Pregnant Teen Dies After Shoveling Snow: Family|url=http://www.nbcphiladelphia.com/news/local/Pregnant-Teenager-Pottstown-Snow-Shoveling-Storm-Pennsylvania-Baby-366312161.html}}{{cite news|author=David Chang|work=[[WCAU]]|publisher=[[NBCUniversal]]|date=January 23, 2016|accessdate=January 25, 2016|title=Elderly Man Dies While Shoveling Snow in Lower Providence: Officials|url=http://www.nbcphiladelphia.com/news/local/Lower-Providence-Shoveling-Death-Montgomery-County-Snowstorm-366313771.html}}{{cite news|work=[[WGAL]]|publisher=[[NBCUniversal]]|date=January 25, 2016|accessdate=January 25, 2016|title=2 Lancaster County men died while clearing snow, coroner reports|url=http://www.wgal.com/news/2-lancaster-county-men-died-while-clearing-snow/37630868|location=Lancaster County, Pennsylvania}} One of the dead in Montgomery County was a woman who was 8-months pregnant; the baby was declared dead on-scene when paramedics arrived.{{cite news|work=[[KFSM-TV]]|publisher=[[Tribune Media]]|date=January 25, 2016|accessdate=January 25, 2016|title=Pregnant Pennsylvania Teen Among Winter Storm’s 11 Snow Shoveling Deaths|url=http://5newsonline.com/2016/01/25/pregnant-teen-dies-after-shoveling-snow-family-says/|location=Pottstown, Pennsylvania}} Another man died from carbon monoxide poisoning in his car in [[Reading, Pennsylvania|Reading]] after a passing snow plow buried his car in snow.{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|work=[[KYW-TV]]|publisher=[[CBS Corporation]]|date=January 24, 2016|accessdate=January 25, 2016|title=Pennsylvania Man Dies After Plow Buries Car|url=http://philadelphia.cbslocal.com/2016/01/24/man-apparently-trapped-in-running-car-by-plow-deluge-dies/|location=Reading, Pennsylvania}} [[File:January 2016 blizzard in Queens, New York.jpg|thumb|right|Near-[[Whiteout (weather)|whiteout]] conditions in [[Briarwood, Queens|Briarwood]], [[Queens]], New York City, during the storm]] One person died in [[Magnolia, Delaware]], after suffering a heart attack while shoveling.{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|work=[[WXMI]]|publisher=[[Tribune Media]]|date=January 27, 2016|accessdate=January 27, 2016|title=Death toll from East Coast snow storm rises to at least 49|url=http://fox17online.com/2016/01/27/death-toll-from-east-coast-snow-storm-rises-to-at-least-49/|location=Grand Rapids, Michigan}} A power outage at the [[Delaware City Refinery]], thought to be related to the storm, forced the facility to shut down after chemicals were released.{{cite news|author=Xerxes Wilson|newspaper=[[The News Journal]]|date=January 23, 2016|accessdate=January 27, 2016|title=Delaware City refinery power outage causes shutdown|url=http://www.delawareonline.com/story/weather/2016/01/23/power-outage-causes-delaware-city-refinery-shutdown/79232236/|location=Wilmington, Delaware}} A mother and her 1-year-old son died from carbon monoxide poisoning in [[Passaic, New Jersey]], after snowfall blocked their vehicle's tailpipe; a 3-year-old girl was hospitalized,{{cite news|author=Checkey Beckford|work=[[WCAU]]|publisher=[[NBCUniversal]]|date=January 24, 2016|accessdate=January 25, 2016|title=1-Year-Old, Mom Killed by Carbon Monoxide as Dad Clears Snow|url=http://www.nbcphiladelphia.com/news/national-international/Boy-1-and-Mom-Killed-by-Carbon-Monoxide-as-Dad-Clears-Snow-Girl-in-Critical-Condition-366354911.html}}{{cite news|author=Lindsey Bever|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|date=January 25, 2016|accessdate=January 26, 2016|title=‘Everybody cry': Mom, 1-year-old killed by carbon monoxide as dad clears snow|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/morning-mix/wp/2016/01/25/everybody-cry-mom-1-year-old-killed-by-carbon-monoxide-as-dad-clears-snow/|location=Washington, D.C.}} but later died on January 27.{{cite news|work=[[KNBC]]|publisher=[[NBCUniversal]]|date=January 27, 2016|accessdate=January 28, 2016|title=New Jersey Girl, 3, Dies After Being Found in Snow-Covered Car|url=http://www.nbclosangeles.com/news/national-international/3-Year-Old-Girl-Dies-Carbon-Monoxide-Snow-Car-Mom-Brother-Dead-Passaic-New-Jersey-366757521.html?_osource=SocialFlowTwt_LABrand|location=Los Angeles, California}} Three other people died while attempting to walk home during the blizzard: one each in [[East Greenwich, New Jersey|East Greenwich]], [[Hackensack, New Jersey|Hackensack]], and [[Mahwah, New Jersey|Mahwah]].{{cite web|author= Rebecca Forand|work=New Jersey On-Line|publisher=[[Advance Digital]]|date=January 25, 2016|accessdate=January 25, 2016|title=Man walking home during blizzard is 4th storm-related death in NJ|url=http://www.nj.com/gloucester-county/index.ssf/2016/01/fourth_nj_storm-related_death_reported_in_south_je.html|location=East Greenwich Township, New Jersey}}{{cite news|author=Jeremy Tanner|work=[[WPIX]]|publisher=[[Tribune Media]]|date=January 25, 2016|accessdate=January 25, 2016|title=Woman found dead under snow in Mahwah, New Jersey|url=http://pix11.com/2016/01/25/woman-found-dead-under-snow-in-mahwah-new-jersey/|location=Mahwah, New Jersey}} Snowfall across New York City and Long Island was more intense than initially forecast, falling at rates of {{convert|3|in|cm|abbr=on}} per hour at times. Before the travel ban was implemented, buses struggled to make their routes and long delays were common.{{cite news|author1=James Barron |author2=Rick Rojas |newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=January 23, 2016|accessdate=January 23, 2016|title=Major Cities Grind to a Halt and Face Days of Digging Out|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/01/24/nyregion/east-coast-snowstorm.html|location=New York, New York}} At [[Central Park]], a storm-total accumulation of {{convert|27.5|in|cm|abbr=on|sigfig=3}} was observed, the highest total on record for the city since observations began in 1869. This surpassed the previous record of {{convert|26.9|in|cm|abbr=on|sigfig=3}} measured during the [[North American blizzard of 2006|February 2006 blizzard]]. Accumulations reached an all-time record high of {{convert|30.5|in|cm|abbr=on}} at John F. Kennedy International Airport. Police across New York City responded to more than 200 accidents and 300 disabled vehicles.{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|newspaper=[[The Morning Call]]|date=January 23, 2016|accessdate=January 23, 2016|title= Snowstorm socks East Coast: A look at the effects by state|url=http://www.mcall.com/news/breaking/mc--big-snowstorm-state-by-state-20160123-story.html|location=Allentown, Pennsylvania}} Emergency personnel responded to about 3,000 [[9-1-1]] calls across the city. Five people died while shoveling snow: two in [[Queens]], two in unknown parts of the city, and one in [[Staten Island]].{{cite news|work=[[WNYW]]|publisher=[[21st Century Fox]]|date=January 24, 2016|accessdate=January 25, 2016|title=5 snow shoveling deaths in New York|url=http://www.fox5ny.com/news/81312270-story|location=New York, New York}}{{cite news|agency=Associated Press|newspaper=The Eagle|date=January 23, 2016|accessdate=January 23, 2016|title=Officials: 3 New Yorkers died shoveling snow during blizzard|url=http://www.theeagle.com/news/nation/officials-new-yorkers-died-shoveling-snow-during-blizzard/article_7607ff9c-ed61-56fd-82b3-80f15aae3dfa.html|location=New York, New York}}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} At least two deaths in Long Island were from shoveling snow.{{cite news|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|last=Stack|first=Liam|date=January 23, 2016|accessdate=January 24, 2016|title=6 People Die While Shoveling Snow|url=https://www.nytimes.com/live/winter-storm-jonas/five-in-new-york-area-die-while-shoveling-snow/}} One person was killed by a snow plow in [[Oyster Bay Cove, New York|Oyster Bay Cove]] on Long Island.{{cite news|work=[[WCBS-TV]]|publisher=[[CBS Corporation]]|date=January 25, 2016|accessdate=January 25, 2016|title=Snow Plow Strikes, Kills Man In Oyster Bay Cove|url=http://newyork.cbslocal.com/2016/01/25/oyster-bay-cove-snow-plow-accident/|location=Oyster Bay Cove}} ====Coastal flooding==== [[File:January 2016 blizzard in Ocean City - transportation center.JPG|thumb|right|Street flooding in [[Ocean City, New Jersey]], on January 23]] Significant coastal flooding took place in Delaware and New Jersey.{{cite news|author=Emily Shapiro|publisher=[[ABC News]]|date=January 23, 2016|accessdate=January 23, 2016|title=Flooding Strikes Jersey Shore as Massive Snowstorm Wallops East Coast|url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/flooding-strikes-jersey-shore-massive-snowstorm-wallops-east/story?id=36467962}} The first, and most severe, round of flooding took place during the morning of January 23. A second round took place after the storm's passage on the morning of January 24, concurrent with high tide.{{cite news|author1=Jon Hurdle |author2=Benjamin Mueller |newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=January 24, 2016|accessdate=January 27, 2016|title=With Morning Tides, More Flooding on Jersey Shore|url=https://www.nytimes.com/live/winter-storm-jonas/flooding-in-new-jersey-2/|location=New York, New York}} Record tides occurred in [[Lewes, Delaware]]. Approximately {{convert|20|mi|km|abbr=on}} of [[dune]]s along Delaware's {{convert|24|mi|km|abbr=on}} oceanfront coast sustained significant damage, with many areas flattened.{{cite news|author=Molly Murray|newspaper=[[The News Journal]]|date=January 25, 2016|accessdate=January 27, 2016|title=Dunes washed away; bayshore beaches flooded|url=http://www.delawareonline.com/story/news/2016/01/24/blizzard-recovery-dunes-washed-away-debris-litters-streets/79171696/|location=Wilmington, Delaware}} Forty people required evacuation in [[Long Neck, Delaware|Long Neck]] and [[Oak Orchard, Delaware|Oak Orchard]].{{cite news|author=Cathy Carter|publisher=[[WDDE]]|date=January 25, 2016|accessdate=January 27, 2016|title= Delaware National Guard came to the rescue over the weekend |url=http://delawarepublic.org/post/delaware-national-guard-came-rescue-over-weekend|location=Dover, Delaware}} [[Delaware Route 1]] was shut down between [[Bethany Beach, Delaware|Bethany Beach]] and [[Dewey Beach, Delaware|Dewey Beach]] for flooding.{{cite news|author=Chris Flood|newspaper=Cape Gazette|date=January 23, 2016|accessdate=January 27, 2016|title=Route 1 remains closed from Dewey to Bethany|url=http://capegazette.villagesoup.com/p/route-1-closed-from-dewey-to-bethany/1472930}} Tides at [[Cape May, New Jersey]], reached a record {{convert|9.26|ft|m|abbr=on}}, surpassing the previous highest of {{convert|8.67|ft|m|abbr=on}} set during [[Hurricane Sandy]] in 2012. Fifty people required evacuation in [[Atlantic City, New Jersey|Atlantic City]], and at least 150 homes were flooded. Strong winds accompanying the flooding caused damage to many homes.{{cite news|work=[[WCAU]]|publisher=[[NBCUniversal]]|date=January 23, 2016|accessdate=January 23, 2016|title=Storm Causes Major Flooding in Several Jersey Shore Towns|url=http://www.nbcphiladelphia.com/news/local/Blizzard-Jersey-Shore-Winter-Storm-Flooding-Sea-Isle-Ocean-City-Cape-May-County-366294841.html}} Streets in [[Ocean City, New Jersey|Ocean City]] and [[Stone Harbor, New Jersey|Stone Harbor]] were inundated with several feet of water; according to a resident in Stone Harbor, water reached {{convert|5|ft|m|abbr=on}} in depth on some streets. Effects were most severe along the [[Delaware Bay]].{{cite web|author=Jon Hurdle|publisher=NJ Spotlight|date=January 27, 2016|accessdate=January 27, 2016|title= Jonas highlights New Jersey's unsolved back-bay flooding problem |url=http://www.newsworks.org/index.php/local/new-jersey-spotlight/90462-jonas-highlights-new-jerseys-unsolved-back-bay-flooding-problem}} Combined with snowfall and freezing temperatures, the flooded roads became a mix of ice and slush. [[Long Beach Island]], still recovering from the effects of Hurricane Sandy, sustained severe [[beach erosion]].{{cite web|author=MaryAnn Spoto|work=New Jersey On-Line|publisher=[[Advance Digital]]|date=January 27, 2016|accessdate=January 27, 2016|title=N.J. wants feds to repair LBI beaches eroded by blizzard soon|url=http://www.nj.com/ocean/index.ssf/2016/01/nj_wants_feds_to_repair_eroded_lbi_beaches.html|location=Holgate, New Jersey}} The storm's tide and waves carved {{convert|15|ft|m|abbr=on}} cliffs along coastal beaches.{{cite news|author=Michael Miller|newspaper=[[Press of Atlantic City]]|date=January 27, 2016|accessdate=January 27, 2016|title=Federal delegation tours flood-damaged South Jersey|url=http://www.pressofatlanticcity.com/communities/atlantic-city_pleasantville_brigantine/federal-delegation-tours-flood-damaged-south-jersey/article_e6c6546c-c4a4-11e5-8fa1-3b1f3399e4ba.html|location=Atlantic City, New Jersey}} A recently constructed dune in [[Belmar, New Jersey|Belmar]] held back most of the water, with one minor breach along its {{convert|1.3|mi|km|abbr=on}} expanse. ===New England=== Blizzard conditions affected southeastern Massachusetts for several hours, with [[Nantucket]] and [[Martha's Vineyard]] reporting such conditions for four hours. Wind gusts on [[Block Island]], Rhode Island, reached {{convert|75|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}.{{cite news|author=Danielle Vollmar|work=[[WCVB-TV]]|publisher=[[Hearst Corporation]]|date=January 24, 2016|accessdate=January 25, 2016|title=5 Massachusetts locations saw blizzard conditions with storm|url=http://www.wcvb.com/weather/5-mass-locations-saw-blizzard-conditions-with-storm/37610034|location=Boston, Massachusetts}} One person died after being struck by a snow plow. ===Newfoundland and Nova Scotia=== After leaving the Eastern United States, the storm complex brought light snowfall to coastal areas of [[Nova Scotia]], Canada, on January 24. [[Environment Canada]] indicated accumulations up to {{convert|5|cm|in|abbr=on}} alongside wind gusts of {{convert|30|to|70|km/h|mph|abbr=on}}. Residents, however, reported up to {{convert|30|cm|in|abbr=on}} of snow in [[Shelburne County, Nova Scotia|Shelburne County]].{{cite news |newspaper=[[The Chronicle Herald]] |date=January 24, 2016 |accessdate=January 26, 2016 |title=Snow for some Nova Scotians, not a flake for others |url=http://thechronicleherald.ca/novascotia/1336813-snow-for-some-nova-scotians-not-a-flake-for-others }} Street parking was banned in [[Halifax, Nova Scotia|Halifax]] on select streets to enable easier clearing of roads.{{cite news |publisher=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]] |date=January 26, 2016 |accessdate=January 26, 2016 |title=Halifax bans parking on 3 streets overnight to clear snow |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/nova-scotia/halifax-parking-ban-1.3419980 }} On January 25, a [[Boeing 767]] traveling from [[Miami]], Florida, to [[Milan]], Italy, encountered severe [[turbulence]] produced by the storm about {{convert|300|mi|km|abbr=on|order=flip}} off [[Newfoundland (island)|Newfoundland]]. Of the 203 people on board, including crew, seven were injured. The aircraft made an emergency landing at [[St. John's International Airport]].{{cite news |first=Nicole |last=Hensley |newspaper=[[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]] |date=January 25, 2016 |accessdate=January 26, 2016 |title=Severe turbulence injures 7 on American Airlines flight to Milan; aircraft diverted to Newfoundland |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/world/turbulence-injures-7-board-american-airlines-milan-article-1.2508262 }} ==Aftermath== [[File:January Blizzard 2016 Montgomery County, Maryland - Potomac road.jpg|thumb|right|Snow depth in [[Montgomery County, Maryland]]]] [[File:Central Park New York January 2016 004.jpg|thumb|left|Partially frozen-over pond in [[Central Park]], [[New York City]]]] [[File:Winter Storm Jonas - Fairfax Villa Neighborhood - Maple Street - 9.JPG|right|thumb|Car stuck in snow on an unplowed road in [[Northern Virginia]] on January 24]] Many cities struggled to cope with the snowfall, including Washington, D.C., where schools and government offices remained closed through January 26, three days after the storm. Schools in Baltimore, Maryland, and Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, also remained closed through January 26. Side streets around the D.C. area were unplowed through January 26.{{cite news|work=[[WTTG]]|publisher=[[21st Century Fox]]|date=January 26, 2016|accessdate=January 26, 2016|title=Unplowed side-streets leave DC area residents furious|url=http://www.fox5dc.com/news/82512932-story|location=Temple Hills, Maryland}} Through January 27, Washington, D.C. police issued $1,078,000 worth of parking tickets and $65,600 in fines for vehicles parked or abandoned on snow emergency routes. At least 656 vehicles were towed.{{cite news|work=[[WRC-TV]]|publisher=[[NBCUniversal]]|date=January 27, 2016|accessdate=January 27, 2016|title=DC Issues $1 Million Worth of Parking Tickets After Blizzard|url=http://www.nbcwashington.com/news/local/DC-Issues-1-Million-Worth-of-Parking-Tickets-After-Blizzard-366711341.html|location=Washington, D.C.}} The ''[[New York Post]]'' described Queens, New York, as "basically forgotten" on January 25 as roads remained covered with snow.{{cite news|author1=Megan McGibney |author2=Michael Gartland |author3=Bruce Golding |newspaper=[[New York Post]]|date=January 25, 2016|accessdate=January 26, 2016|title=Queens was basically forgotten during Winter Storm Jonas|url=https://nypost.com/2016/01/25/queens-was-basically-forgotten-during-winter-storm-jonas/|location=New York, New York}} Many residents complained that snowplows did not come through their area until at least a day after the storm passed. Crews expressed that certain areas, such as in the [[Bronx]], were difficult to navigate with snow plows and there was no place to put the snow. A resident of Pelham Bay stated that [[3-1-1]] operators were not picking up calls. Mayor De Blasio toured areas of Staten Island on January 24 and urged people to be patient.{{cite news|work=[[WCBS-TV]]|publisher=[[CBS Corporation]]|date=January 24, 2016|accessdate=January 26, 2016|title=Some Bronx, Queens, Staten Island Residents Say Plows Neglected Them|url=http://newyork.cbslocal.com/2016/01/24/staten-island-unplowed-streets-snowstorm/|location=New York, New York}} In contrast, both Governor Cuomo and Mayor De Blasio were praised for their handling of the storm prior to its arrival, and for being the first to issue a travel ban, which is credited for potentially saving lives.{{cite news|author1=J. David Goodman |author2=Jesse McKinley |newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=January 25, 2016|accessdate=January 26, 2016|title=De Blasio and Cuomo Find Rare Harmony in Blizzard Response|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/01/26/nyregion/praise-for-de-blasio-and-cuomo-but-complaints-in-queens-after-blizzard.html|location=New York, New York}} New Jersey Governor [[Chris Christie]], who flew back to the state from New Hampshire during [[Chris Christie presidential campaign, 2016|his presidential campaign]], left to resume campaigning shortly after the storm passed. He was criticized for his quick departure and heated responses to questions about why he left the state. He stated that while there was some locally significant flood damage in Southern New Jersey, the overall effects across the state did not warrant his presence. He responded to one person by saying, "I don’t know what you expect me to do. You want me to go down there with a mop?"{{cite news|author=David Chang|work=[[WCAU]]|publisher=[[NBCUniversal]]|date=January 25, 2016|accessdate=January 26, 2016|title='You Want Me to Go Down There With a Mop?' Christie Addresses Criticism Over His Response to Jersey Shore Flooding|url=http://www.nbcphiladelphia.com/news/local/Chris-Christie-New-Jersey-Flooding-Jersey-Shore-366503951.html}}{{cite news|author=Jordyn Phelps|publisher=[[ABC News]]|date=January 25, 2016|accessdate=January 26, 2016|title='Want Me to Go Down There With a Mop?' Chris Christie Says About NJ Flooding Cleanup|url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/mop-chris-christie-nj-flooding-cleanup/story?id=36513815}} A [[Stockton University]] graduate started up a fund to provide 1,000 mops to Christie in response to his comment.{{cite news|author=Diane D'Amico|newspaper=[[The Press of Atlantic City]]|date=January 26, 2016|accessdate=January 26, 2016|title=Stockton grad starts "Mops for Christie" campaign|url=http://www.pressofatlanticcity.com/news/breaking/stockton-grad-starts-mops-for-christie-campaign/article_3763533e-c45a-11e5-927f-dfbd3138df5c.html}} On January 26, Christie apologized to [[North Wildwood, New Jersey|North Wildwood]] Mayor Patrick Rosenello for calling him "crazy" during his response to criticism the day prior. Christie also requested that Rosenello apologize on his behalf to first responders, residents, and business owners.{{cite web|author=Matt Arco|work=New Jersey On-Line|publisher=[[Advance Digital]]|date=January 26, 2016|accessdate=January 26, 2016|title=Christie apologizes to 'crazy mayor'|url=http://www.nj.com/politics/index.ssf/2016/01/christie_apologizes_to_crazy_mayor.html|location=Manchester, New Hampshire}} In March, President [[Barack Obama]] declared Delaware,{{cite web|publisher=[[Federal Emergency Management Agency]]|date=March 4, 2016|accessdate=April 20, 2016|title=President Declares Disaster for Delaware|url=https://www.fema.gov/news-release/2016/03/16/president-declares-disaster-delaware|location=Washington, D.C.}} Maryland,{{cite web|publisher=[[Federal Emergency Management Agency]]|date=March 4, 2016|accessdate=April 20, 2016|title=President Declares Disaster for State of Maryland|url=https://www.fema.gov/news-release/2016/03/04/president-declares-disaster-state-maryland|location=Washington, D.C.}} New Jersey,{{cite web|publisher=[[Federal Emergency Management Agency]]|date=March 15, 2016|accessdate=April 20, 2016|title=President Declares Disaster for State of New Jersey|url=https://www.fema.gov/news-release/2016/03/15/president-declares-disaster-state-new-jersey|location=Washington, D.C.}} Pennsylvania,{{cite web|publisher=[[Federal Emergency Management Agency]]|date=March 23, 2016|accessdate=April 20, 2016|title=President Declares Disaster for Pennsylvania|url=https://www.fema.gov/news-release/2016/03/23/president-declares-disaster-pennsylvania|location=Washington, D.C.}} Virginia,{{cite web|publisher=[[Federal Emergency Management Agency]]|date=March 7, 2016|accessdate=April 20, 2016|title=President Declares Disaster for the Commonwealth of Virginia|url=https://www.fema.gov/news-release/2016/03/07/president-declares-disaster-commonwealth-virginia|location=Washington, D.C.}} and Washington, D.C. major disaster areas.{{cite web|publisher=[[Federal Emergency Management Agency]]|date=March 4, 2016|accessdate=April 20, 2016|title=President Declares Disaster for District of Columbia|url=https://www.fema.gov/news-release/2016/03/04/president-declares-disaster-district-columbia|location=Washington, D.C.}} The federal funding would only cover costs incurred by public infrastructure, debris removal, and emergency measures to ensure public safety.{{cite web|publisher=[[Federal Emergency Management Agency]]|date=March 4, 2016|accessdate=April 20, 2016|title=Federal Aid Programs for the District of Columbia Declaration|url=https://www.fema.gov/news-release/2016/03/04/federal-aid-programs-district-columbia-declaration|location=Washington, D.C.}}{{cite web|publisher=[[Federal Emergency Management Agency]]|date=March 4, 2016|accessdate=April 20, 2016|title=Federal Aid Programs for the state of Maryland Declaration|url=https://www.fema.gov/news-release/2016/03/04/federal-aid-programs-state-maryland-decleration|location=Washington, D.C.}} Preliminary estimates places the total cost of assistance at $168,334,023,{{refn|group=nb|An estimate of federal assistance for Pennsylvania is not available.}} with New Jersey accounting for $82,663,604.{{cite web|publisher=[[Federal Emergency Management Agency]]|date=March 16, 2016|accessdate=April 20, 2016|title=Delaware — Severe Winter Storm and Flooding: FEMA-4265-DR|url=http://www.fema.gov/media-library-data/1460555905251-36578b063e154cb0ccf41a7716bfe9d0/PDAReportFEMA4265DRDE.pdf|location=Washington, D.C.|format=PDF}} * {{cite web|publisher=[[Federal Emergency Management Agency]]|date=March 14, 2016|accessdate=April 20, 2016|title=New Jersey — Severe Winter Storm and Snowstorm: FEMA-4264-DR|url=http://www.fema.gov/media-library-data/1460555304030-5f057f2d86c0b1de019aa3b0adef49c3/PDAReportFEMA4264DRNJ.pdf|location=Washington, D.C.|format=PDF}} * {{cite web|publisher=[[Federal Emergency Management Agency]]|date=March 4, 2016|accessdate=April 20, 2016|title=District of Columbia – Snowstorm: FEMA-4260-DR|url=http://www.fema.gov/media-library-data/1459196123591-d0d0ac1bbf488b2f42d531fca6bec120/FEMA4260DRDC.pdf|location=Washington, D.C.|format=PDF}} * {{cite web|publisher=[[Federal Emergency Management Agency]]|date=March 4, 2016|accessdate=April 20, 2016|title=Maryland — Severe Winter Storm and Snowstorm: FEMA-4261-DR|url=http://www.fema.gov/media-library-data/1459196489320-b1bd57d2ad3c4caf3cc764c207e66c98/FEMA4261DRMD.pdf|location=Washington, D.C.|format=PDF}} * {{cite web|publisher=[[Federal Emergency Management Agency]]|date=March 7, 2016|accessdate=April 20, 2016|title=Virginia — Severe Winter Storm and Snowstorm: FEMA-4262-DR|url=http://www.fema.gov/media-library-data/1460119494869-4c75c5527d9b97d7f785d11e820f33f8/PDAReportFEMA4262DRVA.pdf|location=Washington, D.C.|format=PDF}} ===Snowfall measurement reviews=== Following the storm, the National Weather Service conducted a review of eight snowfall observations following concerns over their quality. Measurements from Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport, Dulles International Airport, Baltimore/Washington International Airport, John F. Kennedy International Airport, LaGuardia International Airport, and Philadelphia International Airport were verified as reliable. The total at Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport was brought into question immediately following the blizzard as the snow observers lost their measuring board during the storm;{{cite news|author1=Angela Fritz |author2=Shawn Boburg |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|date=January 24, 2016|accessdate=April 28, 2016|title=Lower-than-expected D.C. snowfall total raises questions about its measurement|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/capital-weather-gang/wp/2016/01/24/paltry-national-airport-snowfall-total-raises-questions-about-observing-standards/}} however, the assessment determined that proper procedure was continued even after the board was lost and the total was considered accurate. A review of measurements at Central Park, New York, revealed the {{convert|26.8|in|cm|abbr=on}} observation was the result of a communication error and revised the storm-total to {{convert|27.5|in|cm|abbr=on}}—an all-time record for New York City. Furthermore, the {{convert|28.1|in|cm|abbr=on}} measurement at Newark International Airport, New Jersey, was invalidated due to measurements being taken every hour instead of every six hours thus inflating the total.{{cite web|publisher=[[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration]]|date=April 28, 2016|accessdate=April 28, 2016|title=Review of Jan. 2016 blizzard preliminary snow totals validates DC measurement|url=http://www.noaa.gov/review-jan-2016-blizzard-preliminary-snow-totals-validates-dc-measurement}} The State Climate Extremes Committee also conducted a review of a potential 24-hour state snowfall record at Mount Mitchell in North Carolina. Their results showed the 24-hour observation of {{convert|41|in|cm|abbr=on}} to be in error, erroneously inflating the snowfall totals. Properly adjusting for liquid snow ratios, the total was revised to {{convert|21|in|cm|abbr=on}}. The storm-total accumulation was also revised from {{convert|66|in|cm|abbr=on}} to {{convert|33|in|cm|abbr=on}}. {{Clear}} ==Snowfall accumulations and records== {{col-begin}}{{col-break}} {| Airport]] | {{convert|19.4|in|cm|abbr=on|sortable=on}} | Daily (January 23) | |- | Tennessee | [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]] | {{convert|8.0|in|cm|abbr=on|sortable=on}} | Daily (January 22) | |- | Virginia | [[Norfolk, Virginia|Norfolk]] | {{convert|1.2|in|cm|abbr=on|sortable=on}} | Daily (January 23) | |- | Virginia | [[Richmond, Virginia|Richmond]] | {{convert|5.3|in|cm|abbr=on|sortable=on}} | Daily (January 23) | |- | Virginia | [[Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport|Ronald Reagan Washington
National Airport]] | {{convert|11.3|in|cm|abbr=on|sortable=on}} | Daily (January 23) | |- | Virginia | [[Washington Dulles International Airport|Washington Dulles
International Airport]] | {{convert|22.1|in|cm|abbr=on|sortable=on}} | Daily (January 23) | |- | Virginia | [[Wallops Island]] | {{convert|1.0|in|cm|abbr=on|sortable=on}} | Daily (January 23) | |- |} {{col-end}} {{clear}} ==Naming== {{see also|Winter storm naming in the United States}} The storm has received several nicknames from various media outlets. The name ''Winter Storm Jonas'' was created by [[The Weather Channel]] at the beginning of the winter storm season, and assigned to the storm system when it was forecast; it has also been used in international media,{{cite news|language=French|agency=[[Agence France-Presse]] and [[Reuters]]|newspaper=[[Le Monde]]|date=January 22, 2016|accessdate=January 22, 2016|title=La côte est des Etats-Unis en alerte maximale avant l’arrivée de la tempête géante Jonas|url=http://www.lemonde.fr/ameriques/article/2016/01/22/la-cote-est-des-etats-unis-se-prepare-a-l-arrivee-de-la-tempete-jonas_4851604_3222.html|location=Paris, France}} *{{cite news|author=Alexandra Sims|newspaper=[[The Independent]]|date=January 22, 2016|accessdate=January 22, 2016|title=Winter Storm Jonas: 'Full-blown bread and milk freak out' erupts as blizzards threaten East Coast|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-snowstorm-full-blown-bread-and-milk-freak-out-erupts-as-blizzards-threaten-east-coast-a6826726.html|location=London, United Kingdom}} and was used by New York City Mayor [[Bill de Blasio]]{{Cite tweet|user=BilldeBlasio|number=690754553701101568|date=22 January 2016|title=Jonas is here, NYC. Please be safe. Stay off the roads and look out for your neighbors.}} and the [[United States Postal Service]].{{Cite web|url=http://about.usps.com/news/state-releases/ny/2016/ny_2016_0122a.htm|title=NY Postal Officials Preparing for Storm Jonas|first=Connie|last=Chiricello|date=January 22, 2016|accessdate=January 23, 2016|publisher=[[United States Postal Service]]}} Reception of the naming of storms has been mixed; ''[[The New York Times]]'' refers to the name "Jonas" as a marketing ploy while The Weather Channel maintains that it helps others prepare in advance.{{cite news|author=Liam Stack|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=January 22, 2016|accessdate=January 22, 2016|title=Meet Jonas, Part Storm, Part Marketing Ploy|url=https://www.nytimes.com/live/winter-storm-jonas/weather-channel-storm-naming-tk/}} ''[[The Washington Post]]'' named the storm [[Snowmageddon|Snowzilla]], referencing the [[2014–16 El Niño event]] which has been named the "[[Godzilla]] El Niño".{{cite news|author=Angela Fritz|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|date=January 22, 2016|accessdate=January 22, 2016|title=We hereby name this winter storm ‘Snowzilla’|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/capital-weather-gang/wp/2016/01/21/poll-name-this-winter-storm/|location=Washington, D.C.}}{{cite news|url=http://www.newsday.com/news/nation/snowzilla-is-no-jonas-but-it-just-may-make-make-winter-great-again-in-washington-d-c-1.11354037|title=‘Snowzilla’ is no ‘Jonas,’ but it just may make ‘Make Winter Great Again’ in Washington, D.C.|newspaper=[[Newsday]]|author=Patricia Kitchen|date=January 22, 2016|accessdate=January 22, 2016}} Connecticut-based [[WFSB]] named the system ''Anna'', after former [[First Lady of the United States|First Lady]] [[Anna Harrison]].{{cite web|work=[[WFSB]]|publisher=[[Meredith Corporation]]|date=January 21, 2016|accessdate=January 22, 2016|title=Weekend Storm – the latest!|url=http://www.wfsb.com/story/31015194/tracking-the-potential-for-a-winter-storm-this-weekend|location=Hartford, Connecticut}} Other sources have dubbed the storm simply ''Blizzard of 2016'' or ''Blizzard 2016''.{{cite news|author=Mark Weiner|newspaper=[[The Post-Standard]]|date=January 22, 2016|accessdate=January 22, 2016|title=As Blizzard of 2016 roars up coast, Washington, D.C. begins massive shutdown|url=http://www.syracuse.com/weather/index.ssf/2016/01/as_blizzard_of_2016_roars_up_coast_washington_dc_begins_massive_shutdown.html|location=Syracuse, New York}} *{{cite news|author=Eileen Whelan|work=[[WJLA-TV]]|publisher=[[Sinclair Broadcast Group]]|date=January 22, 2016|accessdate=January 22, 2016|title=The day is here! D.C. braces for Blizzard 2016|url=http://wjla.com/news/local/only-hours-to-go-until-the-blizzard-of-2016-are-you-ready|location=Washington, D.C.}} *{{cite news|author=Robinson Meyer|newspaper=[[The Atlantic]]|date=January 22, 2016|accessdate=January 28, 2016|title=What’s the Name of the 2016 Blizzard?|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/science/archive/2016/01/whats-the-name-of-the-2016-blizzard/426696/|location=Boston, Massachusetts}} ==See also== *[[Knickerbocker Storm]] *[[North American blizzard of 1996]] – Essentially an analog of the 2016 blizzard, with similar snow totals and areas affected. *[[December 2009 North American blizzard]] *[[February 5–6, 2010 North American blizzard]] *[[February 9–10, 2010 North American blizzard]] *[[February 2016 North American winter storm]] *[[Early January 2017 North American winter storm]] *[[Mid-January 2017 North American ice storm]]
