revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2017}} {{EngvarB|date=August 2017}} [[File:Stonehenge in Context 2 - geograph.org.uk - 1434969 (cropped).jpg|thumb|Traffic on the A303 road passing by Stonehenge]]
The '''Stonehenge road tunnel''' is a planned tunnel in [[Wiltshire]], England drawn up by [[Highways England]] to upgrade the [[A303 road]]. It would move the A303 into a tunnel under the [[Stonehenge]] [[World Heritage Site]], completing the removal of traffic begun with the closure of the [[A344 road (England)|A344 road]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.highways.gov.uk/roads/projects/8311.aspx |title=Reasons for Review |publisher=Highways Agency |accessdate=2007-04-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Hicks|first1=Dan|title=Why are England's heritage bodies supporting the Stonehenge Bypass?|url=https://www.apollo-magazine.com/englands-heritage-bodies-supporting-stonehenge-bypass/|work=Apollo|date=24 February 2017}}</ref> The wider project was designed to improve the landscape around the monument and to improve safety on the A303,<ref name="ha">{{cite web |url=http://www.highways.gov.uk/roads/projects/3659.aspx |title=A303 Stonehenge |publisher=Highways Agency |accessdate=2007-04-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120804012024/http://www.highways.gov.uk/roads/projects/3659.aspx |archivedate=4 August 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> and was part of proposals to change the site in other ways including moving the visitors centre.
==Context== [[File:A303(T) Queues at Stonhenge - geograph.org.uk - 34458.jpg|thumb|right|250px|The A303 road passing by Stonehenge]] The A303 [[primary route]] is one of the main routes from London to the [[South West England|South West of England]]. Sections have been upgraded to [[dual carriageway]] status, though one third of the road remains single carriageway. Traffic flows on the A303 between [[Amesbury]] and [[Winterbourne Stoke]] (the section including Stonehenge) are above the capacity of the road<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.highways.gov.uk/roads/projects/6382.aspx |title=A303 Stonehenge (incorporating the Winterbourne Stoke Bypass) Preferred Route Announcement June 1999 – Why a road improvement is proposed |publisher=Highways Agency |accessdate=2007-04-08}}</ref> and the Highways Agency expressed concern about safety on this road and the A344. The two roads passed through Stonehenge and land owned by the National Trust<ref name="report">{{cite web |url=http://www.dft.gov.uk/pgr/roads/network/strategic/programme/decisionletters/coll_reportofthelocalinquiryinto/reportofthelocalinquiryintot3987 |title=Report to the First Secretary of State and the Secretary of State for Transport |page=8 |date=31 January 2005 |format=PDF |accessdate=2007-07-08 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070206194011/http://www.dft.gov.uk/pgr/roads/network/strategic/programme/decisionletters/coll_reportofthelocalinquiryinto/reportofthelocalinquiryintot3987 <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate=2007-02-06}}</ref> with the A303 passing directly south and the A344 directly to the north, with a pedestrian tunnel passing from the Stonehenge visitor centre to the site underneath this road. As part of the development of the proposals, over 50 routes were considered by the Highways Agency.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.highways.gov.uk/roads/projects/6381.aspx |title=A303 Stonehenge (incorporating the Winterbourne Stoke Bypass) Preferred Route Announcement June 1999 – Choice of route |publisher=Highways Agency |accessdate=2007-04-08}}</ref>
Since 1991, 51 proposals have been considered for improving the A303 in the area and to remove it from the Stonehenge site.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.unesco.org.uk/UserFiles/File/UKNC_Stonehenge_042006.pdf |title=A303 Stonehenge Improvement Scheme Review: public consultation — Response by the United Kingdom National Commission for UNESCO |accessdate=2007-05-17 |author=Professor Alec Boksenberg CBE FRS |date=19 April 2006 |format=PDF |publisher=UNESCO Committee for United Kingdom |pages=2}}</ref>
==Proposals==
===1995 proposal=== In 1995 it was proposed to build a tunnel for the A303 underneath the World Heritage Site. A conference agreed on a 2.5-mile (4 km) [[tunnel|bored tunnel]]; however, the [[United Kingdom government|government]] instead proposed a [[cut and cover]] tunnel, with plans being published in 1999. These plans were criticised by the [[National Trust for Places of Historic Interest or Natural Beauty|National Trust]], [[Campaign for Better Transport (United Kingdom)|Transport 2000]] and others who expressed concern that it would cause damage to archaeological remains along the route, destroy ancient sites and not achieve an improvement in the landscape.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/1606053.stm |title=Stonehenge road plans 'may damage site' |publisher=BBC News |date=18 October 2001 |accessdate=2007-04-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/2299033.stm |title=Trust attacks Stonehenge tunnel |publisher=BBC News |date=4 October 2002 |accessdate=2007-04-08}}</ref>
In 2002, new plans for a bored tunnel of 1.3 miles (2.1 km) were announced by the [[Secretary of State for Transport]] as part of a 7.7-mile (12.5 km) plan to upgrade the A303 to dual carriageway status, with the tunnel estimated to cost [[£]]183 million.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/2562675.stm |title=Stonehenge tunnel approved |publisher=BBC News |date=10 December 2002 |accessdate=2007-04-08}}</ref> This proposal brought further protests from the National Trust, [[English Heritage]], [[UNESCO]], [[Campaign to Protect Rural England|CPRE]], the [[Council for British Archaeology]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.britarch.ac.uk/stonehenge/Stonehenge%20roads%20inquiry%20final%20proof.doc|title=Proof of Evidence of George Lambrick MA FSA MIFA|last=|first=|date=January 2004|website=|publisher=Council for British Archaeology|format=DOC|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=2007-04-08}}</ref> and local groups as the tunnel approach cutting would cut in two a prehistoric track way between Stonehenge and a nearby river. These groups are calling for a tunnel at least 2.9 km long, which would, while being sited within the world heritage site, clear most of the known major artefacts, claiming that if the government goes ahead with the 2.1 km tunnel there may never be another chance to remove the road from the site completely.<ref>{{cite press release|title=Maximising benefits – A more sustainable tunnel solution at Stonehenge|date=|publisher=The National Trust|url=http://www.nationaltrust.org.uk/webpack/bin/webpack.exe/livebase?object=LiveBase1&itemurn=1247&mode=wbFullItem|accessdate=2007-05-17}}</ref>
In 2004 a [[public enquiry]]<ref name="enquirybegins">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/wiltshire/3493649.stm|title=Stonehenge tunnel inquiry opens|date=17 February 2004|accessdate=2007-04-08|publisher=BBC News}}</ref> required under the [[Highways Act 1980]] was conducted by a planning inspector, Michael Ellison. His enquiry agreed that the government proposals were adequate.<ref name="report"/> The report stated:
{{cquote|The physical loss of archaeological remains, the changes to the land form in these sections, and the scale of the new highway would adversely affect the authenticity of the site and more than offset the benefits of the proposed tunnel in the central area. The published scheme would represent the largest earthwork ever constructed within the World Heritage Site; a feature that would contribute nothing to the authenticity.}}
but concluded:
{{cquote|...after taking into account the requirements of local and national planning, including the requirements of agriculture, that it is expedient for the purpose of improving the A303 between points A and B on the plan referred to in the Line Order for a trunk road to be provided along the route shown in the Line Order}}
On 20 July 2005 the tunnel scheme was withdrawn by the Government, partly due to rising costs of construction, which had doubled to £470 million.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/wiltshire/4699477.stm |title= Stonehenge tunnel plan cash blow |publisher=BBC News |date=20 July 2005 |accessdate=2007-04-08}}</ref> The Highways Agency continued to list the project as planned, but gave 2008 as the earliest date for the start of construction.<ref name="ha" />
===2005 proposal=== On 31 October 2005 a Government steering group was set up to look at possible solutions,<ref>{{cite press release |title=Way Forward Announced For A303 Stonehenge Review |publisher=Government News Network |date=31 October 2005 |url=http://www.gnn.gov.uk/environment/fullDetail.asp?ReleaseID=175616&NewsAreaID=2&NavigatedFromDepartment=False |accessdate=2007-04-08 |quote=Stephen Ladyman, Minister of State for Transport, said: "I hope this review will enable me to decide on an option in keeping with the special requirements of the location that is affordable, realistic and deliverable." |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930155037/http://www.gnn.gov.uk/environment/fullDetail.asp?ReleaseID=175616&NewsAreaID=2&NavigatedFromDepartment=False |archivedate=30 September 2007 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> with the aim of choosing an "option in keeping with the special requirements of the location that is affordable, realistic and deliverable." The review presented five options – the published tunnel scheme, a cut and cover tunnel, a 'partial solution' (involving a roundabout but maintaining the current road), and two overland bypass routes.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/wiltshire/4694894.stm |title=Heritage site road plans revealed |publisher=BBC News |date=8 February 2006 |accessdate=2007-04-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.highways.gov.uk/roads/documents/Stonehenge_Leaflet_web_version.pdf |title=A303 Stonehenge Improvement Scheme Review – Public Consultation |publisher=Highways Agency |format=PDF |date=January 2006 |accessdate=2007-04-08}}</ref> Some of these plans have been criticised as being damaging to both archaeology and [[biodiversity]], including the [[stone curlew]], [[barn owl]]s, [[bat]]s, and the chalk grassland habitat.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/wiltshire/4637656.stm |publisher=BBC News |title=Stonehenge road 'a risk to birds' |date=23 January 2006 |accessdate=2007-04-08}}</ref> Five options were considered including diverting the A303 further away and only closing the A344. The group expected to produce a report in 2006, taking into account the results of public consultation which started on 23 January 2006 and ran until 24 April 2006.<ref name="ha" />
On 6 December 2007, Roads Minister [[Tom Harris (UK politician)|Tom Harris]] announced that the whole scheme had been cancelled due to increased costs of £540 million. English Heritage expressed disappointment whilst the group Save Stonehenge (now Stonehenge Alliance) were pleased with the outcome. The Highways Agency stated that they would continue to work on small scale improvements to the A303.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/wiltshire/7130666.stm |publisher=BBC News |title=Stonehenge tunnel plans scrapped |date=6 December 2007 |accessdate=2007-12-06}}</ref>
===A344 closure=== A revised proposal, of closing the [[A344 road (England)|A344 road]] between Stonehenge Bottom and Byway 12, and closing part of the B3086 was put forward in 2010. This also included a proposed new roundabout to replace the current Airman's Corner junction and improvements to the Longbarrow Roundabout on the A303.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.salisburyjournal.co.uk/news/9097436.Public_inquiry_into_Stonehenge_road_closure/ |title=Public inquiry into Stonehenge road closure |work=Salisbury Journal |date=22 June 2011 |accessdate=2011-08-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bajrfed.co.uk/showthread.php?2771-Stonehenge-Road-Closure |title=Stonehenge Road Closure |publisher=BAJR archaeology portal |date=February 2010 |accessdate=2011-08-12}}</ref>
A planning inquiry to consider the proposal was started in June 2011.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-wiltshire-13863143 |title=Inquiry into Stonehenge A344 closure plans |publisher=BBC |date=22 June 2011 |accessdate=2011-08-12}}</ref> In July 2012 work began on the £27 million project which involved the closure and grassing over of part of the A344 and the closing of the underpass beneath the road at the monument entrance.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2012/jul/11/stonehenge-27-million-makeover-a344|title=Stonehenge's £27m makeover will end its days as a traffic island |work=The Guardian |date=11 July 2012 |accessdate=2012-09-02}}</ref>
In December 2013 the new visitors' centre at Airman's Corner on the [[A360 road|A360]] was opened. Shuttle buses take visitors to the monument along the old A344 road, a distance of approximately 2.4 km.
===2013 proposal=== According to documentation released in response to a [[Freedom of Information Act 2000|Freedom of Information]] request, in January 2012 local councils and the South West Local Enterprise Partnership met to discuss their proposals for "a consortium of Local Authorities to develop and take forward a new scheme for improvements to the A303/ A358/A30" and to "develop an effective lobbying framework so that we can take a planned approach to raising our profile both nationally, regionally and locally".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.whatdotheyknow.com/request/101507/response/257007/attach/3/ENV%20767%20Rebecca%20Lush%20Blum%20Reply%20attachment%20A303%20Meeting%206%20January%202012.pdf|title=Notes of a meeting to discuss opportunities to take forward a new proposal for improvements to the A303, A358 and A30}}</ref> In September 2012 a survey conducted by Somerset County Council found that more than 90% of commuters and businesses in the South West back an upgrade of the A303.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-19615859|title=A303 dualling plan through South West 'supported by businesses'}}</ref> In April 2013 it was reported that the chancellor was giving consideration to "...adding lanes to the A303 – known all too well to holidaymakers – which runs from Basingstoke through Wiltshire (past Stonehenge) and Somerset to the South West of England..."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/chancellor-plans-second-toll-motorway-in-major-road-spend-8556198.html|title=Chancellor plans second toll motorway in major road spend|work=The Independent|date=1 April 2013}}</ref>
===2017 go-ahead=== The proposal was finally allowed by the Government on 12 January 2017. The Transport Secretary, [[Chris Grayling]], said that "it will transform the A303, cutting congestion and improving journey times". Chairman of Amesbury Museum and Heritage Trust, Andy Rhind-Tutt, described the tunnel plan as a "self-destructing time bomb" which would "do nothing" for traffic problems in the area. The Stonehenge Alliance campaign group repeated their belief that "any tunnel shorter than 2.7 miles would cause irreparable damage to the landscape".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-wiltshire-38589118|title=Stonehenge tunnel plan finalised by government|publisher=BBC News|date=12 January 2017|access-date=2017-01-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Hicks|first1=Dan|title=The A303 is part of the Stonehenge setting, don't bury it|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/science/archaeology/the-a303-is-part-of-the-stonehenge-setting-dont-bury-it-a7543226.html|work=The Independent|date=24 January 2017}}</ref> The group also responded with a statement:<ref name="stoneall">{{cite web|url=http://stonehengealliance.org.uk/stonehenge-alliance-responds-and-calls-for-a-re-run/|title=Stonehenge Alliance responds and calls for a re-run|date=3 March 2017|work=Stonehenge Alliance}}</ref>
{{cquote|We object strongly to the short tunnel scheme and address archaeological, natural environment, landscape and transport considerations. We highlight the incompatibility of the short tunnel project with Government’s commitment to the World Heritage Convention, its own planning guidance and policies, and the widely agreed World Heritage Site Management Plan 2015. We note a number of statements in the Technical Appraisal Report that indicate the scheme cannot be considered ‘value for money’.}}
Highways England held consultations on the scheme in 2018. A cost of £1.6 billion and a planned start date in 2021 were indicated.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://highwaysengland.co.uk/projects/a303-stonehenge-amesbury-and-berwick-down/|title=A303 Stonehenge|last=|first=|date=|website=Highways England|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=22 September 2018}}</ref> [[English Heritage]], the [[National Trust for Places of Historic Interest or Natural Beauty|National Trust]] and [[Historic England]] are quoted as supporting the concept of the tunnel with some concerns about the linking of byways, whilst the Stonehenge Alliance and [[Friends of the Earth]] remain opposed<ref name="guard2018">{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2018/feb/08/stonehenge-tunnel-plans-scheme-published|title=Stonehenge tunnel: plans for £1.6bn scheme published|author=Steven Morris|date=8 February 2018|work=The Guardian}}</ref>, as are the [[Campaign for Better Transport (United Kingdom)|Campaign for Better Transport]].<ref name="cbt2018">{{cite web|url=https://bettertransport.org.uk/media/july/2018-stonehenge-consultation|title=New Stonehenge consultation fails to address UNESCO’s concerns|date=5 July 2018|work=Campaign for Better Transport}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060629052601/http://www.planning-inspectorate.gov.uk/stonehenge/index.htm 2004 planning enquiry] *[http://www.savestonehenge.org.uk/ Save Stonehenge] - Now the Stonehenge Alliance *[https://web.archive.org/web/20160209211301/http://www.archaeologyuk.org/conservation/stonehenge Council for British Archaeology’s Stonehenge/A303 timeline, 2010] – archived on 9 February 2016 *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110822081835/http://www.english-heritage.org.uk/daysout/properties/stonehenge/our-plans/ 'Our Plans for Stonehenge: English Heritage] – archived on 22 August 2011 * [https://www.nationaltrust.org.uk/stonehenge-landscape/features/tunnel-will-remove-a303-from-stonehenge-landscape The National Trust's proposals for Stonehenge, December 2014] * [http://www.andyworthington.co.uk 'Stonehenge: Celebration and Subversion' by Andy Worthington (chapter on Stonehenge road tunnel)] *[http://stonehengealliance.org.uk/ Stonehenge Alliance] - Stonehenge campaign group

revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contributions/41.215.254.164|41.215.254.164]] ([[User talk:41.215.254.164|talk]]) ([[WP:HG|HG]]) (3.4.4)
revision.text:
{{Infobox mine | name = Tenke Fungurume Mine | image = | width = | caption = | pushpin_map = Democratic Republic of the Congo | pushpin_label_position = top | pushpin_label = | pushpin_map_alt = | pushpin_mapsize = | pushpin_map_caption = | coordinates = {{coord|10.568411|S|26.195633|E|region:CD-KA|format=dms|display=inline,title}} | place = | subdivision_type = Province | state/province = [[Katanga Province]] | country = [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]] | owner = | official website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> | acquisition year = | stock_exchange = | stock_code = | products = Copper, cobalt | financial year = | amount = | opening year = {{Start date|2009}} | active years = | closing year = }} The '''Tenke Fungurume Mine''' holds one of the world's largest known copper and cobalt resources. The deposits are located within two concessions totaling over {{convert|1500|km2|sqmi}} within [[Katanga Province]], in the south eastern region of the [[Democratic Republic of Congo]] (DRC).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.eib.org/projects/news/tenke-fungurume-mining-project,-democratic-republic-of-congo-drc.htm |title=Tenke Fungurume Mining project, Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) |publisher=[[European Investment Bank]] |date=2007-02-08 |accessdate=2009-04-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090309160826/http://www.eib.org/projects/news/tenke-fungurume-mining-project,-democratic-republic-of-congo-drc.htm |archivedate=March 9, 2009 |df= }}</ref>
Tenke Fungurume is the largest copper mine in the DRC.
==Ownership==
The mining project is a partnership led by [[Freeport-McMoRan|Freeport-McMoRan Copper and Gold]], the [[Lundin Mining|Lundin Mining Corporation]], and the government of the Democratic Republic of Congo, through [[Gécamines]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fcx.com/operations/africa.htm |title=Africa Project |publisher=Freeport-McMoRan |date= |accessdate=2009-04-10 }}</ref>
As of September 2009 Freeport-McMoRan operated the mine and held 58.8%, Lundin held 24.8% and Gécamines (La Générale des Carrières et des Mines) held the remaining 17.5%. In May 2016, Freeport-McMoRan sold their stake to [[China Molybdenum]] (CMOC) for 2.65 Billion USD, as the area holds [[cobalt]] for [[lithium-ion battery|lithium-ion batteries]] in addition to copper.<ref>[https://www.ft.com/content/054bbb3a-1e8b-11e6-a7bc-ee846770ec15 China plays long game on cobalt and electric batteries] FT</ref> The contract had yet to be reviewed by the government under a "revisitation" process started earlier that year.
The first phase at the mine cost US$1.8bn to build.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.proactiveinvestors.com/companies/news/2450/first-quantum-minerals-suspends-kolwezi-tailings-copper-mine-development-2450.html |work=Proactive Investors |title=First Quantum Minerals suspends Kolwezi Tailings Copper Mine Development |date=18 Sep 2009 |author=Barry Seargent |accessdate=2011-11-07}}</ref>
==Operations== The first copper cathode was produced in March 2009, and the plant was working at planned capacity by September 2009. In the third quarter of 2009 the cobalt plant and the sulphuric acid plant were commissioned. It is expected that the operation will produce {{convert|250000000|lb|kg}} of copper metal and {{convert|18000000|lb|kg}} of cobalt annually.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.fcx.com/operations/AfricaTenke.htm |title = Tenke Fungurume |publisher = Freeport-McMoRan Copper & Gold |accessdate = 2011-11-07 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20111102040049/http://www.fcx.com/operations/AfricaTenke.htm |archivedate = 2011-11-02 |df = }}</ref>
==See also== * {{C|Copper mining in the Democratic Republic of the Congo}} *[[Lundin Mining]] *[[Freeport-McMoRan]] *[[Phelps Dodge]]
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Cobalt mines]] [[Category:Copper mines in the Democratic Republic of the Congo]] [[Category:Katanga Province]] [[Category:2009 establishments in the Democratic Republic of the Congo]] [[Category:Non-renewable resource companies established in 2009]]

revision.comment: /* Triflate salts */
revision.text:
[[File:Triflate.png|right|150px|thumb|Triflate group]] [[File:Triflate-anion.png|right|150px|thumb|Triflate [[anion]]]] '''Triflate''', also known by the systematic name '''trifluoromethanesulfonate''', is a [[functional group]] with the formula CF<sub>3</sub>SO<sub>3</sub>−. The triflate group is often represented by −OTf, as opposed to −Tf ([[trifluoromethylsulfonyl|triflyl]]). For example, ''n''-butyl triflate can be written as CH<sub>3</sub>CH<sub>2</sub>CH<sub>2</sub>CH<sub>2</sub>OTf.
The corresponding triflate anion, {{chem|CF|3|SO|3|−}}, is an extremely stable [[polyatomic ion]], being the [[conjugate acid|conjugate base]] of [[triflic acid]] (CF<sub>3</sub>SO<sub>3</sub>H), one of the strongest [[acid]]s known. It is defined as a [[superacid]], because it is more acidic than pure [[sulfuric acid]].
==Applications== A triflate group is an excellent [[leaving group]] used in certain [[organic reactions]] such as [[nucleophilic substitution]], [[Suzuki coupling]]s and [[Heck reaction]]s. Since alkyl triflates are extremely reactive in [[SN2 reaction|S<sub>N</sub>2 reactions]], they must be stored in conditions free of [[nucleophile]]s (such as [[water]]). The anion owes its stability to [[resonance stabilization]] which causes the negative charge to be spread over the three oxygen atoms and the sulfur atom. An additional stabilization is achieved by the [[trifluoromethyl]] group as a strong [[electron-withdrawing group]].
Triflates have also been applied as ligands for group [[Group 11 element|11]] and [[Group 13 element|13]] metals along with [[lanthanide]]s.
Lithium triflates are used in some [[lithium ion batteries]] as a component of the [[electrolyte]].
A mild '''triflating reagent''' is phenyl triflimide or ''N'',''N''-bis(trifluoromethylsulfonyl)aniline, where the by-product is [CF<sub>3</sub>SO<sub>2</sub>N−Ph]<sup>−</sup>.
[[File:Triflate mesomeric stability transp.png|center|thumb|600px|Triflate mesomeric stability]]
==Triflate salts== Triflate [[Salt (chemistry)|salt]]s are thermally very stable with melting points up to 350 °C for [[sodium]], [[boron]] and [[silver]] salts especially in water-free form. They can be obtained directly from triflic acid and the metal hydroxide or metal carbonate in water. Alternatively, they can be obtained from reacting metal chlorides with neat triflic acid or [[silver triflate]], or from reacting [[barium triflate]] with metal sulfates in water:<ref>{{ cite journal | journal = [[Inorganic Syntheses]] | title = Trifluoromethanesulfonates and Trifluoromethanesulfonato-''O'' Complexes |author1=Dixon, N. E. |author2=Lawrance, G. A. |author3=Lay, P. A. |author4=Sargeson, A. M. |author5=Taube, H. | volume = 28 | pages = 70–76 | doi = 10.1002/9780470132593.ch16 | year = 1990 }}</ref>
:MCl<sub>''n''</sub> + ''n'' HOTf → M(OTf)<sub>''n''</sub> + ''n'' HCl :MCl<sub>''n''</sub> + ''n'' AgOTf → M(OTf)<sub>''n''</sub> + ''n'' AgCl ↓ :M(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>''n''</sub> + ''n'' Ba(OTf)<sub>2</sub> → M(OTf)<sub>2''n''</sub> + ''n'' BaSO<sub>4</sub> ↓
Metal triflates are used as [[Lewis acid]] catalysts in [[organic chemistry]]. Especially useful are the [[lanthanide triflates]] of the type Ln(OTf)<sub>3</sub> (where Ln = lanthanide). A related popular catalyst [[scandium triflate]] is used in such reactions as [[aldol reaction]]s and [[Diels-Alder reaction]]s. An example is the [[Mukaiyama aldol addition]] reaction between [[benzaldehyde]] and the [[silyl enol ether]] of [[cyclohexanone]] with an 81% [[chemical yield]].<ref>{{cite journal | author = Kobayashi, S. | title = Scandium Triflate in Organic Synthesis | journal = European Journal of Organic Chemistry | volume = 1999 | issue = 1 | pages = 15–27 | doi = 10.1002/(SICI)1099-0690(199901)1999:1<15::AID-EJOC15>3.0.CO;2-B}}</ref> The corresponding reaction with the [[yttrium]] salt fails:
[[Image:ScOTf3-mediated aldol condensation transp.png|600px|center|ScOTf3-mediated aldol condensation]]
Triflate is a commonly used [[counterion]] for organometallic complexes.
==See also== * [[Methyl triflate]] * [[Nonaflate]] * [[Trifluoromethanesulfonic acid]] * [[Metal triflimidate]] * [[Comins' reagent]]
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Sulfonic acids]] [[Category:Leaving groups]] [[Category:Triflates| ]] [[Category:Anions]] [[Category:Trifluoromethyl compounds]]

{{Use Australian English|date=October 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2016}} The '''West Australian Forest Alliance''' is an organization made up of a number of [[West Australia]]n environmental activist groups—concerned with the destruction of [[Old Growth Forest]]s in the [[South West (Western Australia)|South West]] region. It is a successor to and includes membership of the earlier groups the [[Campaign to Save Native Forests]], [[South West Forests Defence Foundation]], [[Great Walk Networking]], and other member groups of the [[Conservation Council of Western Australia]]
==Affiliated groups== As found on the WAFA website - (Warning: not all of the groups listed were still currently active in 2016).
* Augusta Margaret River Friends of the Forest * [[Australian Conservation Foundation]] * Balingup Friends of the Forest * Blackwood Environment Society * Bridgetown-Greenbushes Friends of the Forest · * Busselton Dunsborough Environment Centre * Busselton Peace and Environment Group * Collie Conservation Group * [[Conservation Council of Western Australia|Conservation Council of WA]] * Darlington Adopt-A-Block * Denmark Conservation Society * Denmark Environment Centre * D'Entrecasteaux Coalition * Doctors for the Preservation of Old Growth Forest * Earth * Friends of the Blackwood Valley * Friends of Giblett * Friends of Jane * Friends of Kingston * Friends of the Tuart Forest * Grassroots Activist Forest Alliance * Greater Beedelup National Park Society * [[Great Walk Networking]] * Leeuwin Conservation Group * Margaret River Environment Centre * South Coast Environment Group * South West Environment Centre · * South West Forests Defence Foundation Inc.<ref>[https://southwestforestdefence.org/ South West Forest Defence]</ref> * [[The Wilderness Society, Australia |The Wilderness Society]] of WA<ref>http://www.wilderness.org.au/regions/wa/ </ref> * Warren Environment Group
==See also== *[[Woodchipping]]
==Newsletter== * The Real forest news. Perth, W.A. : Western Australian Forest Alliance, 1992-1995. Ed. 1 (Dec. 1992)-ed. 6 (Feb. 1995). * Forest campaign bulletin. Perth, W.A. : Western Australian Forest Alliance, 1994- * Western Australian forest times. Perth, W.A. : Western Australian Forest Alliance, 1999 irregular
==Notes== {{reflist|30em}}
==References== * Crawford, Patricia, and Carwford, Ian (2003) ''Contested country : a history of the Northcliffe area, Western Australia''. Nedlands, W.A. : University of Western Australia Press. {{ISBN|1-920694-00-5}} "The Charles and Joy Stapes South West Region Publications Fund". * Lines, William J. (2006) ''Patriots : defending Australia's natural heritage'' St. Lucia, Qld. : University of Queensland Press, 2006. {{ISBN|0-7022-3554-7}} * Schultz, Beth (1997) ''Giblett Block. - W.A. Forest Alliance outlines the significance of this old growth forest and reasons for its preservation.'' [[Great Walk Networking|Great walk news]] July 1997, p. 1-3,
==External links== * http://www.wafa.org.au/
{{environmental-org-stub}}
[[Category:Conservation in Western Australia]] [[Category:Environmental organisations based in Australia]] [[Category:Forests of Western Australia]]
